Only +1 as I'm not sure if we need any additional testing of this in the Neutron stable/stein gate to ensure all of the various q-agt backends are covered?"}, {'account_id': 8864, 'date': '2019-07-16 13:43:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

We're only concerned about OVS, but as on master we have the following matrix of possibilities:

               single-host | multi-host |
  OVS hybrid |      A      |      B     |   
  OVS normal |      C      |      D     |

A: In master this was covered by neutron-tempest-iptables_hybrid in experimental
B: We'd need to bring [1] to stable/stein
C: Our regular tempest-full-py3 job should cover this
D: We had test_server_connectivity_cold_migration_revert, but I have a patch to skip that
  because it's broken in other ways, so we'd need to reuse [1] form B, but in 2 patches
  instead of squashing everything into 1 patch: 1 patch to run revert tests in nova-live
  migration (tests D), 1 patch to turn on hybrid plug (tests B).

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/664442/"}, {'account_id': 10135, 'date': '2019-07-16 13:48:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

check experimental'}, {'account_id': 10135, 'date': '2019-07-17 08:28:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2

Thanks to Artom and Sean I'm raising my +1 to a +2 given the DNM change I3e53c76812ac6614d10a7fdbbc0584c81a4b60b2 is now testing the same combinations that were previously tested on master."}, {'account_id': 30381, 'date': '2019-07-21 22:19:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-07-22 13:28:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Regarding testing, we could have a DNM neutron stable/stein test-only patch that depends on this patch to make sure we run neutron-tempest-iptables_hybrid correct? That would cover the single-node ovs hybrid plug case (the patch on top of this tests the multi-node case).'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-07-22 14:12:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Oh nevermind, I see neutron-tempest-iptables_hybrid was added to the check queue in https://review.opendev.org/#/c/671079/ so it already ran there.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-07-22 18:26:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

LGTM and the conflict is noted and tests in the change on top of this are passing.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-07-12 20:20:07.000000000', 'message': 'Revert resize: wait for events according to hybrid plug

Since 4817165fc5938a553fafa1a69c6086f9ebe311af, when reverting a
resized instance back to the source host, the libvirt driver waits for
vif-plugged events when spawning the instance. When called from
finish_revert_resize() in the source compute manager, libvirt's
finish_revert_migration() does not pass vifs_already_plugged to
_create_domain_and_network(), making the latter use the default False
value.

When the source compute manager calls
network_api.migrate_instance_finish() in finish_revert_resize(), this
updates the port binding back to the source host. If Neutron is
configured to use OVS hybrid plug, it will send the vif-plugged event
immediately after completing this request. This happens before the
virt driver's finish_revert_migration() method is called. This causes
the wait in the libvirt driver to time out because the event is
received before Nova starts waiting for it.

The neutron ovs l2 agent sends vif-plugged events when two conditions
are met. First the port must be bound to the host managed by the
l2 agent and second, the agent must have completed configuring the
port on ovs. This involves assigning the port a local VLAN for tenant
isolation, applying security group rules if required and applying
QoS policies or other agent extensions like service function chaining.

During the boot process, we bind the port first to the host
then plug the interface into ovs which triggers the l2 agent to
configure it resulting in the emission of the vif-plugged event.
In the revert case, as noted above, since the vif is already plugged
on the source node when hybrid-plug is used, binding the port to the
source node fulfils the second condition to send the vif-plugged event.

Events sent immediately after port binding update are hereafter known
as "bind-time" events. For ports that do not use OVS hybrid plug,
Neutron will continue to send vif-plugged events only when Nova
actually plugs the VIF. These types of events are hereafter known as
"plug-time" events. OVS hybrid plug is a per agent setting, so for
a particular host, bind-time events are an all-or-nothing thing for the
ovs backend: either all VIF_TYPE=ovs ports have them, or no ovs ports
have them. In general, a host will only have one network backend.
The only exception to this is SR-IOV. SR-IOV is commonly deployed on
the same host as other network backends such as OVS or linuxbridge.
SR-IOV ports with VNIC_TYPE=direct-physical will always have only
bind-time events. If an instance mixes OVS ports with hybrid-plug=False
with direct physical ports, it will have both kinds of events.

For same host resize reverts we do not update the binding host as the
host does not change, as such for same host resize we do not receive
bind time events. For same host revert we therefore do not wait for
bind time events in the compute manager.

This patch adds functions to the NetworkInfo model that return what
kinds of events each VIF has. These are then used in the migration
revert logic to decide when to wait for external events: in the
compute manager, when binding the port, for bind-time events,
and/or in libvirt, when plugging the VIFs, for plug-time events.

(cherry picked from commit 7a7a223602ca5aa0aca8f65a6ab143f1d8f8ec1b)
Conflicts in nova/tests/unit/objects/test_migration.py due to
1cf3da87027d87251920c2df665b850abb31178e's addition of
test_obj_make_compatible() and test_get_by_uuid().

Closes-bug: #1832028
Closes-Bug: #1833902
Co-Authored-By: Sean Mooney <work@seanmooney.info>
Change-Id: I51673e58fc8d5f051df911630f6d7a928d123a5b

commit_message:
Revert resize: wait for events according to hybrid plug

Since 4817165fc5938a553fafa1a69c6086f9ebe311af, when reverting a
resized instance back to the source host, the libvirt driver waits for
vif-plugged events when spawning the instance. When called from
finish_revert_resize() in the source compute manager, libvirt's
finish_revert_migration() does not pass vifs_already_plugged to
_create_domain_and_network(), making the latter use the default False
value.

When the source compute manager calls
network_api.migrate_instance_finish() in finish_revert_resize(), this
updates the port binding back to the source host. If Neutron is
configured to use OVS hybrid plug, it will send the vif-plugged event
immediately after completing this request. This happens before the
virt driver's finish_revert_migration() method is called. This causes
the wait in the libvirt driver to time out because the event is
received before Nova starts waiting for it.

The neutron ovs l2 agent sends vif-plugged events when two conditions
are met. First the port must be bound to the host managed by the
l2 agent and second, the agent must have completed configuring the
port on ovs. This involves assigning the port a local VLAN for tenant
isolation, applying security group rules if required and applying
QoS policies or other agent extensions like service function chaining.

During the boot process, we bind the port first to the host
then plug the interface into ovs which triggers the l2 agent to
configure it resulting in the emission of the vif-plugged event.
In the revert case, as noted above, since the vif is already plugged
on the source node when hybrid-plug is used, binding the port to the
source node fulfils the second condition to send the vif-plugged event.

Events sent immediately after port binding update are hereafter known
as "bind-time" events. For ports that do not use OVS hybrid plug,
Neutron will continue to send vif-plugged events only when Nova
actually plugs the VIF. These types of events are hereafter known as
"plug-time" events. OVS hybrid plug is a per agent setting, so for
a particular host, bind-time events are an all-or-nothing thing for the
ovs backend: either all VIF_TYPE=ovs ports have them, or no ovs ports
have them. In general, a host will only have one network backend.
The only exception to this is SR-IOV. SR-IOV is commonly deployed on
the same host as other network backends such as OVS or linuxbridge.
SR-IOV ports with VNIC_TYPE=direct-physical will always have only
bind-time events. If an instance mixes OVS ports with hybrid-plug=False
with direct physical ports, it will have both kinds of events.

For same host resize reverts we do not update the binding host as the
host does not change, as such for same host resize we do not receive
bind time events. For same host revert we therefore do not wait for
bind time events in the compute manager.

This patch adds functions to the NetworkInfo model that return what
kinds of events each VIF has. These are then used in the migration
revert logic to decide when to wait for external events: in the
compute manager, when binding the port, for bind-time events,
and/or in libvirt, when plugging the VIFs, for plug-time events.

(cherry picked from commit 7a7a223602ca5aa0aca8f65a6ab143f1d8f8ec1b)
Conflicts in nova/tests/unit/objects/test_migration.py due to
1cf3da87027d87251920c2df665b850abb31178e's addition of
test_obj_make_compatible() and test_get_by_uuid().

Closes-bug: #1832028
Closes-Bug: #1833902
Co-Authored-By: Sean Mooney <work@seanmooney.info>
Change-Id: I51673e58fc8d5f051df911630f6d7a928d123a5b

commit_message:
Remove the stable/stein branch for Patrole

Patrole is branchless with "cycle-with-intermediary" model
and does not create the stable branch with same reason as
Tempest.

Below commit added the stable/stein for Patrole which is not
correct- https://review.opendev.org/#/c/650173

This commit removes the branching from stein patrole release.

As next step, we will add some type(as proposed by ttx[1]) or
tag to make it clear that Patrole does not need branch.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/670808/

Change-Id: Ib11838bc87e4fe0a350d107184be68e837233891

subject: Use systemd-journald instead of log files
messages:

commit_message:
Use systemd-journald instead of log files

This patch aims to migrate service from usage of  rsyslog to journald.
By this we mean dropping rsyslog client installation and
set log address to /dev/log, which is served by journald.

Change-Id: I80dccb129e73fd58f7211bd56d36e55b55603c6a

(3 comments)

Interesting.

This was added via [1] where, up to PS4 [2], it generated an exception. As an exception, preventing a subsequent failure of a cold migration per the bug report [3], it might be worthwhile to keep around. But as a warning, I agree it's probably not worth the cost of gathering all the IPs on the system.

But before I vote on this, I would like dims (author of [1]) and Dan (who asked for [2]) to weigh in. We may want to try harder to find a cheaper way of discovering whether CONF.my_ip is legit so we can keep the warning.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/153906/
[2] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/153906/4/nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py@2442
[3] https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1419002"}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2019-07-19 14:31:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> This was added via [1] where, up to PS4 [2], it generated an
 > exception. As an exception, preventing a subsequent failure of a
 > cold migration per the bug report [3], it might be worthwhile to
 > keep around. But as a warning, I agree it's probably not worth the
 > cost of gathering all the IPs on the system.

It's not just a warning it fails earlier. For situations (as I noted in my comment) where CONF.my_ip isn't going to be assigned to an interface, the fast-fail will be wrong.

I think it might be worthwhile doing this once at startup and logging a warning, but definitely not raising an exception like what is there today."}, {'account_id': 8864, 'date': '2019-07-19 15:42:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 8864, 'date': '2019-07-19 15:44:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

...Otherwise this lgtm, makes me much happier than the outright removal.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-07-19 16:02:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

Upon further prodding, it seems probable that we're now running the real netifaces.interfaces() in all the *other* tests where init_host gets invoked, which is probably not a good thing. We should fixture out get_machine_ips() or netifaces.interfaces() at some higher level."}, {'account_id': 8864, 'date': '2019-07-19 16:08:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-07-19 16:40:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

[{'created': '2019-07-18 12:26:01.000000000', 'message': "migrations: libvirt: remove get_machine_ips()

Migrations use the libvirt driver's get_host_ip_addr() method to
determine the dest_host field of the migration object.
get_host_ip_addr() checks whether CONF.my_ip is actually assigned to
one of the host's interfaces. It does so my calling
get_machine_ips(), which interates over all of the host's interfaces.
If the host has many interfaces, this can take a long time, and

get_machine_ips() is ony used to print a warning, this patch removes

Change-Id: I58a4038b04d5a9c28927d914e71609e4deea3d9f
"}, {'created': '2019-07-18 15:59:30.000000000', 'message': "migrations: libvirt: remove get_machine_ips()

Migrations use the libvirt driver's get_host_ip_addr() method to
determine the dest_host field of the migration object.
get_host_ip_addr() checks whether CONF.my_ip is actually assigned to
one of the host's interfaces. It does so my calling
get_machine_ips(), which interates over all of the host's interfaces.
If the host has many interfaces, this can take a long time, and
introduces needless delays in processing the migration. As
get_machine_ips() is ony used to print a warning, this patch removes
it and the warning entirely.

An alternative would have been to cache the result of
get_machine_ips(). However, the result from get_machine_ips() is only
used to print a warning about CONF.my_ip. No breakage is prevented in
case CONF.my_ip is misconfigured or if that IP address disappears from
the host during a migration.

Closes-bug: 1837075
Change-Id: I58a4038b04d5a9c28927d914e71609e4deea3d9f

get_host_ip_addr() checks whether CONF.my_ip is actually assigned to
one of the host's interfaces. It does so by calling
get_machine_ips(), which iterates over all of the host's interfaces.
If the host has many interfaces, this can take a long time, and
introduces needless delays in processing the migration.
get_machine_ips() is only used to print a warning, so this patch moves
the get_machine_ips() call to a single method in init_host(). This
way, a warning is still emitted at compute service startup, and
migration progress is not needlessly slowed down.

Closes-bug: 1837075

"}, {'created': '2019-07-19 19:23:34.000000000', 'message': "libvirt: move checking CONF.my_ip to init_host()

Migrations use the libvirt driver's get_host_ip_addr() method to
determine the dest_host field of the migration object.
get_host_ip_addr() checks whether CONF.my_ip is actually assigned to

get_machine_ips(), which iterates over all of the host's interfaces.
If the host has many interfaces, this can take a long time, and
introduces needless delays in processing the migration.
get_machine_ips() is only used to print a warning, so this patch moves
the get_machine_ips() call to a single method in init_host(). This
way, a warning is still emitted at compute service startup, and
migration progress is not needlessly slowed down.

This patch also has a chicken and egg problem with the patch on top of
it, which poisons use of netifaces.interfaces() in tests. While this
patch fixes all the tests that break with that poison, it starts
breaking different tests because of the move of get_machine_ips() into
init_host(). Therefore, while not directly related to the bug, this
patch also preventatively mocks or stubs out any use of
get_machine_ips() that will get poisoned with the subsequent patch.

Closes-bug: 1837075
Change-Id: I58a4038b04d5a9c28927d914e71609e4deea3d9f
"}]
commit_message:
libvirt: move checking CONF.my_ip to init_host()

Migrations use the libvirt driver's get_host_ip_addr() method to
determine the dest_host field of the migration object.
get_host_ip_addr() checks whether CONF.my_ip is actually assigned to
one of the host's interfaces. It does so by calling
get_machine_ips(), which iterates over all of the host's interfaces.
If the host has many interfaces, this can take a long time, and
introduces needless delays in processing the migration.
get_machine_ips() is only used to print a warning, so this patch moves
the get_machine_ips() call to a single method in init_host(). This
way, a warning is still emitted at compute service startup, and
migration progress is not needlessly slowed down.

This patch also has a chicken and egg problem with the patch on top of
it, which poisons use of netifaces.interfaces() in tests. While this
patch fixes all the tests that break with that poison, it starts
breaking different tests because of the move of get_machine_ips() into
init_host(). Therefore, while not directly related to the bug, this
patch also preventatively mocks or stubs out any use of
get_machine_ips() that will get poisoned with the subsequent patch.

Closes-bug: 1837075
Change-Id: I58a4038b04d5a9c28927d914e71609e4deea3d9f

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-06-17 14:07:48.000000000', 'message': 'Fix diskimage-create.sh datasources

The variable passed to diskimage-builder that configures the
cloud-init datasources was incorrect. This can lead to longer
startup times as cloud-init will check many other datasources.

Change-Id: Ifa5d6107e66520b8e5610e44aefdc1dc833d2b0b
'}, {'created': '2019-06-17 14:14:44.000000000', 'message': 'Fix diskimage-create.sh datasources

Set the cloud-init datasources to configdrive for all
distrobutions.

Change-Id: Ifa5d6107e66520b8e5610e44aefdc1dc833d2b0b
'}, {'created': '2019-07-19 22:14:34.000000000', 'message': 'Fix diskimage-create.sh datasources

Set the cloud-init datasources to configdrive for all
distrobutions.

Change-Id: Ifa5d6107e66520b8e5610e44aefdc1dc833d2b0b
'}]
commit_message:
Fix diskimage-create.sh datasources

Set the cloud-init datasources to configdrive for all
distrobutions.

Change-Id: Ifa5d6107e66520b8e5610e44aefdc1dc833d2b0b

commit_message:
Add spec for glusterfs-direcotry-layout-extend-shrink-share

Enable extend and shirnk apis for GlusterFS native driver with
directory mapped layout.

Change-Id: I2e9dbc8e10ac3105887ccd2bf16696da64fe4638

commit_message:
Add Python 3 Train unit tests

This is a mechanically generated patch to ensure unit testing is in place
for all of the Tested Runtimes for Train.

See the Train python3-updates goal document for details:
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/train/python3-updates.html

Change-Id: I29a89ee1abbbfaa7d9593923c17f8999b9323d25
Story: #2005924
Task: #34215

commit_message:
Use upper-constraints

Using upper-constraints in the keystone-specs tox environment ensures
that libraries go through validation in the requirements project and
don't break our CI.

Change-Id: Ic38c11bec5fe50c7fff7c1f4dec86504a29ba222

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-07-22 20:01:05.000000000', 'message': "Correct style errors

These style errors weren't caught before the specs merged because the
linter jobs weren't being run when only RST files were changed. Correct
them now so that a later patch can update the jobs.

Change-Id: I1c24cece2c64c9453698280cc365ac150d2474a4
"}, {'created': '2019-07-22 20:11:40.000000000', 'message': "Correct style errors

These style errors weren't caught before the specs merged because the
linter jobs weren't being run when only RST files were changed. Correct
them now so that a later patch can update the jobs.

Change-Id: I1c24cece2c64c9453698280cc365ac150d2474a4
"}]
commit_message:
Correct style errors

These style errors weren't caught before the specs merged because the
linter jobs weren't being run when only RST files were changed. Correct
them now so that a later patch can update the jobs.

Change-Id: I1c24cece2c64c9453698280cc365ac150d2474a4

commit_message:
remove releasenotes mitaka references

They cause ``tox`` to fail when run locally  because there is no
stable/mitaka branch for this component.

Change-Id: Ia5d56f3761e89e16e8a4c586502b2b0c31291dd8

commit_message:
Update api-ref location

The api documentation is now published on docs.openstack.org instead
of developer.openstack.org. Update all links that are changed to the
new location.

Note that redirects will be set up as well but let's point now to the
new location.

For details, see:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-July/007828.html

Change-Id: I69a41aa850c87e92bf5c3e7fed32e0e961a3c6d3

commit_message:
Sync Sphinx requirement

1. Sync sphinx dependency with global requirements. It caps python 2 since
sphinx 2.0 no longer supports Python 2.7.
2. Remove unncessary "=="

Change-Id: Ifa7e58304e8d2cc5b34fe8ba5fff580e0cb0e823

[{'created': '2019-07-18 18:10:36.000000000', 'message': "Run stable/rocky linters on ubuntu bionic

spec-cleaner 1.1.4 doesn't install with python3.5 because it introduced
type annotations which aren't available until python3.6[1]. This change
overrides the openstack-tox-linter job definition to always use the
ubuntu-bionic nodeset so that we can use a modern version of python3
instead of conditionally choosing an ubuntu version based on the branch.

[1] https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0526/

Change-Id: Ic97642185ea04f317d876d961a57cb9782571f9e
"}]
commit_message:
Run stable/rocky linters on ubuntu bionic

spec-cleaner 1.1.4 doesn't install with python3.5 because it introduced
type annotations which aren't available until python3.6[1]. This change
overrides the openstack-tox-linter job definition to always use the
ubuntu-bionic nodeset so that we can use a modern version of python3
instead of conditionally choosing an ubuntu version based on the branch.

[1] https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0526/

Change-Id: Ic97642185ea04f317d876d961a57cb9782571f9e

subject: Add --name-lookup-one-by-one option to server list
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 970, 'name': 'Dean Troyer', 'email': 'dtroyer@gmail.com', 'username': 'dtroyer'}, {'_account_id': 9542, 'name': 'Pavlo Shchelokovskyy', 'email': 'pshchelokovskyy@mirantis.com', 'username': 'pshchelo'}, {'_account_id': 10338, 'name': 'Daniel Speichert', 'email': 'daniel@speichert.pl', 'username': 'daniel'}, {'_account_id': 13252, 'name': 'Dr. Jens Harbott', 'display_name': 'Dr. Jens Harbott (frickler)', 'email': 'frickler@offenerstapel.de', 'username': 'jrosenboom'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 9542, 'date': '2018-05-14 18:17:52.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10338, 'date': '2018-05-14 18:22:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

This change makes the number of API requests more predictable.'}, {'account_id': 9542, 'date': '2018-05-14 18:23:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

one potential drawback is that a request returning many servers with very varying images/flavors (something like --all-projects) might in fact become slower.

may be consider a CLI flag, or use old mechanism when --all-projects is given'}, {'account_id': 10338, 'date': '2018-05-14 18:34:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Ideally it would be a CLI option to choose between: "no" image name resolution, "ondemand" image name resolution or "preload" image name resolution (default=preload for backwards compat).'}, {'account_id': 9542, 'date': '2018-05-15 13:15:00.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 9542, 'date': '2018-05-15 13:16:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Workflow-1

needs moar unit tests'}, {'account_id': 10338, 'date': '2018-05-15 15:12:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I think the '--name-lookup' option may be confusing, the term is typically associated with DNS names. Since DNSaaS is a thing in OpenStack, it may suggest some sort of IP->hostname lookup magic.  My alternative suggestions are particularly obvious but that's what I have: --resolve-related or --related-lookup."}, {'account_id': 10338, 'date': '2018-05-15 16:14:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

See comment above'}, {'account_id': 9542, 'date': '2018-05-16 07:55:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Daniel,

there is already '--no-name-lookup' option, so configuring the opposite of it seems natural to be named '--name-lookup'. Besides help string clearly states what this is doing IMO"}, {'account_id': 10338, 'date': '2018-05-16 14:25:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1

You convinced me, great change.'}, {'account_id': 9542, 'date': '2018-05-17 16:58:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 9542, 'date': '2018-05-18 13:46:42.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 9542, 'date': '2018-06-05 10:49:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 9542, 'date': '2018-06-13 13:21:17.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4: Patch Set 3 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 9542, 'date': '2018-06-20 17:42:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 9542, 'date': '2018-07-09 16:12:19.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 13252, 'date': '2018-07-10 13:29:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2018-07-10 16:49:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

This needs a release note and doc update too.

I have reservations about --name-lookup having an argument. it feels like there should be a third option here, something like --name-lookup-one (although that may not be meaningful to users).

OSC generally prefers to use multiple exclusive options rather than an option with arguments, particularly when the number is unlikely to be expanded over time (think --enable|--disable).'}, {'account_id': 9542, 'date': '2018-07-12 19:36:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 9542, 'date': '2018-09-25 12:36:53.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 9542, 'date': '2018-09-25 12:38:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

Dean, changed to `--name-lookup-one-by-one` toggle option and added a release note.
Docs seem to be auto-updated on build, or is there another place where this new option must be mentioned?'}, {'account_id': 10338, 'date': '2018-10-23 14:29:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 13252, 'date': '2018-10-24 05:52:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: Code-Review+1

(2 comments)

I'm wondering whether we really need to place the burden of choosing the proper option for a cloud onto the user. How about automating it: Make an initial call to listing images/flavors with a limit like 20, and if we get more results, switch to one-by-one lookup. Can someone with access to such a large cloud verify that doing a limited listing works reasonably fast as compared to a full listing?

Probably that automation could be added as a followup, though we might be needing separate options for flavors & images?"}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2018-11-02 17:01:53.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2018-11-02 17:06:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: Code-Review+2

I tweaked on the release note a little and made the help text updates frickler suggested.

Pavlo if you will +1 my edits we'll be ready to (finally) merge this"}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2018-11-08 17:32:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2019-07-22 19:56:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Cherry Picked

This patchset was cherry picked to branch stable/rocky as commit dda007ba33b5c7d1ae539926b826749727276e3c'}]

[{'created': '2018-05-14 18:17:52.000000000', 'message': 'Resolve images and flavors one by one in server list

usually in a big cloud there are many images and flavors,
while each given project might use only some of those.

Instead of making a full image/flavor list when doing server list and
attempting to resolve image/flavor ids to names,
make specific GET requests to unique set of flavors and images present
in the server objects returned by the server list.

Change-Id: I59cbf3f75c55e5d3747654edcc9be86ad954cf40

while each given project might use only some of those.

This patch introduces '--name-lookup' argument to server list command
(mutually exclusive with '--no-name-lookup') with possible values of:
  - 'all' (default) keeps current behavior of fetching all
    images/flavors at once;
  - 'one' makes specific GET requests to unique set of images/flavors
    present in the server objects returned by the server list.

When either '--image' or '--flavor' is specified, name resolving for
corresponding entity is now also using targeted GET commands instead of
full entities list.

commit_message:
Add --name-lookup-one-by-one option to server list

usually in a big cloud there are many images and flavors,
while each given project might use only some of those.

This patch introduces '--name-lookup-one-by-one' argument to
server list command (mutually exclusive with '--no-name-lookup')

When provided (or either '--image' or '--flavor' is specified) to the
`server list` command, name resolving for
corresponding entity is now using targeted GET commands instead of
full entities list.

In some situations this can significantly speedup the execution of the
`server list` command by reducing the number of API requests performed.

Change-Id: I59cbf3f75c55e5d3747654edcc9be86ad954cf40
Story: #2002039
Task: #19682

> I don't think this is necessary and people still use venvs for

The ''run_tests.sh' has already been removed,  there is no way to generate the '.venv' directory again."}, {'account_id': 14320, 'date': '2018-09-09 08:20:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 11628, 'date': '2019-07-22 19:55:03.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

There has been no activity on this patch for a year, abandoning.'}]

commit_message:
Modify the 'tox.ini' file

Since the horizon remove the 'run_tests.sh' file,
so there should remove '.venv' from the '.tox.ini' file.

Change-Id: I2f643478a2c3384362939e21d7801adc6651a9a5

commit_message:
Manila PowerMax - rebrand from VMAX to PowerMax

Rebrand from VMAX to PowerMax includes change tags, directory structure,
file names and documentation.

Implements: blueprint powermax-rebrand-manila

Change-Id: Ie9ba5939b223d7061a3b2707ee9ef899f1fe7f66

commit_message:
Update api-ref location

The api documentation is now published on docs.openstack.org instead
of developer.openstack.org. Update all links that are changed to the
new location.

Note that the location API location /shared-file-system and not
/shared-file-systems.

Note that redirects will be set up as well but let's point now to the
new location.

For details, see:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-July/007828.html

Change-Id: I86f50af83be699fa7e0fb064abb20324e2d87b86

subject: Lower the memcache_socket_timeout to one second
messages:
[{'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2019-07-22 15:00:17.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2019-07-22 15:02:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

(1 comment)

Seems reasonable to me. We changed this to a float specifically because it was desirable to set lower timeouts.

One nit inline, but that can be ninja fixed before merge or done in a followup.'}, {'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2019-07-22 16:51:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2019-07-22 17:53:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-07-22 15:00:17.000000000', 'message': 'Lower the memcache_socket_timeout to one second

Lowering this setting still allows for reasonable confidence of a
timeout without tanking performance.

Certain downstream projects have already made this optimization:

  https://github.com/crowbar/crowbar-openstack/pull/1429

Change-Id: Iaca2f8cc09a6acae425c020a9d14da3ffde05dec
'}]
commit_message:
Lower the memcache_socket_timeout to one second

Lowering this setting still allows for reasonable confidence of a
timeout without tanking performance.

Certain downstream projects have already made this optimization:

  https://github.com/crowbar/crowbar-openstack/pull/1429

Change-Id: Iaca2f8cc09a6acae425c020a9d14da3ffde05dec

commit_message:
Update UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/stein

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/stein branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I8bee326cd9704022cb7e01fe40cbdec6e76be823

messages: [{'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-07-22 13:23:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-07-22 13:23:59.000000000', 'content': 'Topic changed from lookup-one-by-one-bfv-stable/stein to lookup-one-by-one-bfv'}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2019-07-22 15:15:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1\n\nLGTM, clean backport.'}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2019-07-22 16:52:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-07-22 13:23:51.000000000', 'message': "Fix BFV server list handling with --name-lookup-one-by-one

When the --name-lookup-one-by-one option passed to the 'server list'
command, the image and flavor names will be looked up for each
server being listed instead of fetching all image/flavor names.

The current code assumes all servers have an image attribute, but
servers booted from volumes have no image, so the following error is
raised when listing BFV servers with --name-lookup-one-by-one:

  AttributeError: ('unicode'|'str') object has no attribute 'get'

The error occurs when the code attempts server.image.get('id').

This fixes the --name-lookup-one-by-one code not to assume an image
for a server. The unit tests for 'server list' have also been
robustified to feature one BFV server to enhance our test coverage.

Story: #2006063
Task: #34777

Change-Id: I312c971346c7ded93f6fcaa515098554b8580295
(cherry picked from commit bfc34e11b3437506508b3e120accc0e212268ac6)
"}]
commit_message:
Fix BFV server list handling with --name-lookup-one-by-one

When the --name-lookup-one-by-one option passed to the 'server list'
command, the image and flavor names will be looked up for each
server being listed instead of fetching all image/flavor names.

The current code assumes all servers have an image attribute, but
servers booted from volumes have no image, so the following error is
raised when listing BFV servers with --name-lookup-one-by-one:

  AttributeError: ('unicode'|'str') object has no attribute 'get'

The error occurs when the code attempts server.image.get('id').

This fixes the --name-lookup-one-by-one code not to assume an image
for a server. The unit tests for 'server list' have also been
robustified to feature one BFV server to enhance our test coverage.

Story: #2006063
Task: #34777

Change-Id: I312c971346c7ded93f6fcaa515098554b8580295
(cherry picked from commit bfc34e11b3437506508b3e120accc0e212268ac6)

subject: [DNM] testing bug/1813789 revert resize events
messages: [{'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2019-07-16 15:22:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2019-07-16 15:27:51.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-07-22 18:27:41.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned\n\nNo longer needed.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-07-16 15:22:23.000000000', 'message': "[DNM] testing bug/1813789 revert resize events

This is a combination of 3 commits.
which have been modifed to test revert resize on
stable branches.

This is the 1st commit message:

  Run revert resize tests in nova-live-migration

  In order to test multinode resize revert (which is currently only
  tested in the single node tempest-full-py3 job), this patch renames
  the nova-live-migration job to nova-multinode and makes it run revert
  resize test via a Tempest RC file. The existing live migration and
  evacuate tests are left as post-test hook scripts because they do
  things like change Tempest settings, start Glance, and force down
  compute nodes.

  Change-Id: I980177410c16ecbd809856440ac633453fa20ea8

This is the commit message #2:

  [DNM] use iptables in nova-multinode

  This patch is jsut for testing to see if we can repoduce the
  issue we are seeing downstrem upstream.

  my current working theroy is because we are using iptables
  in the downstream ci which enable the hybrid plug workflow it
  change the timeing of when the network events are sent.

  in a non hybrid plug case the network events are sent after the
  vm is resumed and libvirt plugs the interface back into ovs
  in the hybrid plug case as we have not called unplug on the souce
  node the veth pair and intermeidate linux bridge still exist when
  we activate the souce binding so the event woudl be sent imedetly before
  we start waithgin for it. this is what we belive is the souce of the
  bug and this shoudl hopefully repoduce it.

  Change-Id: Idf0ed84bae0bedbb70b5a65ee804ec1f2f4a27ee

This is the commit message #3:

  Add neutron-tempest-iptables_hybrid job to experimental queue

  Due to regression bug 1833902 we should have the option to
  run the neutron job that tests the OVS hybrid plug configuration
  on specific patches.

  We could eventually consider running this in the check queue
  like neutron-tempest-linuxbridge with a strict set of irrelevant
  files but that would require some thought, i.e. we'd want to run
  the job on changes to nova/compute/manager.py since the network
  vif model bind events code is used in the ComputeManager and is
  specific to OVS hybrid plug ports. Rather than get bogged down in
  thinking up what that set is, this change takes the easy path and
  just throws the job into the on-demand experimental queue.

  Change-Id: Id5172d97b349abe59b47d1284e97943091652419
  Related-Bug: #1833902

this modifed versions of those commits will run
3 jobs in the check queue
  - nova-live-migration
  - nova-live-migration-iptables
  - neutron-tempest-iptables_hybrid

nova-live-migartion and the iptables variant
will test teh multi node case
and the neutron-tempest-iptables_hybrid will test
same host resize.

Change-Id: I3e53c76812ac6614d10a7fdbbc0584c81a4b60b2
"}, {'created': '2019-07-16 15:27:51.000000000', 'message': "[DNM] testing bug/1813789 revert resize events

commit_message:
[DNM] testing bug/1813789 revert resize events

This is a combination of 3 commits.
which have been modifed to test revert resize on
stable branches.

This is the 1st commit message:

  Run revert resize tests in nova-live-migration

  In order to test multinode resize revert (which is currently only
  tested in the single node tempest-full-py3 job), this patch renames
  the nova-live-migration job to nova-multinode and makes it run revert
  resize test via a Tempest RC file. The existing live migration and
  evacuate tests are left as post-test hook scripts because they do
  things like change Tempest settings, start Glance, and force down
  compute nodes.

  Change-Id: I980177410c16ecbd809856440ac633453fa20ea8

This is the commit message #2:

  [DNM] use iptables in nova-multinode

  This patch is jsut for testing to see if we can repoduce the
  issue we are seeing downstrem upstream.

  my current working theroy is because we are using iptables
  in the downstream ci which enable the hybrid plug workflow it
  change the timeing of when the network events are sent.

  in a non hybrid plug case the network events are sent after the
  vm is resumed and libvirt plugs the interface back into ovs
  in the hybrid plug case as we have not called unplug on the souce
  node the veth pair and intermeidate linux bridge still exist when
  we activate the souce binding so the event woudl be sent imedetly before
  we start waithgin for it. this is what we belive is the souce of the
  bug and this shoudl hopefully repoduce it.

  Change-Id: Idf0ed84bae0bedbb70b5a65ee804ec1f2f4a27ee

This is the commit message #3:

  Add neutron-tempest-iptables_hybrid job to experimental queue

  Due to regression bug 1833902 we should have the option to
  run the neutron job that tests the OVS hybrid plug configuration
  on specific patches.

  We could eventually consider running this in the check queue
  like neutron-tempest-linuxbridge with a strict set of irrelevant
  files but that would require some thought, i.e. we'd want to run
  the job on changes to nova/compute/manager.py since the network
  vif model bind events code is used in the ComputeManager and is
  specific to OVS hybrid plug ports. Rather than get bogged down in
  thinking up what that set is, this change takes the easy path and
  just throws the job into the on-demand experimental queue.

  Change-Id: Id5172d97b349abe59b47d1284e97943091652419
  Related-Bug: #1833902

this modifed versions of those commits will run
3 jobs in the check queue
  - nova-live-migration
  - nova-live-migration-iptables
  - neutron-tempest-iptables_hybrid

nova-live-migartion and the iptables variant
will test teh multi node case
and the neutron-tempest-iptables_hybrid will test
same host resize.

Change-Id: I3e53c76812ac6614d10a7fdbbc0584c81a4b60b2

subject: slo: Better handle non-manifest responses when refetching manifest
messages:
[{'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2019-07-20 04:45:13.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2019-07-20 04:45:58.000000000', 'content': 'Topic changed from py3-func-tests to slo-416'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2019-07-20 15:42:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 9625, 'date': '2019-07-22 14:52:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2019-07-22 15:42:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 9625, 'date': '2019-07-22 16:19:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

on IRC we discussed some of the opinionated decisions made on this patch. main points are. After a re-fetch this is the new behavior:

 - If we find a newer 404 (with tombstone) then that is returned
 - If we get a 404 without timestamp (probably a handoff) we return a 503
 - if we get older (stale) SLO manifest, we serve that to client.'}, {'account_id': 9625, 'date': '2019-07-22 16:43:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2019-07-22 16:51:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-07-20 04:45:13.000000000', 'message': "slo: Better handle non-manifest responses when refetching manifest

Previously, we never checked whether the response we get when refetching
is even successful, much less whether it's still coming from an SLO.

Now, if the refetched data is newer, act on it. If it's older, 503.

Closes-Bug: #1837270
Change-Id: I106b94c77da220c762869aa800c31b87c3dffeeb
"}]
commit_message:
slo: Better handle non-manifest responses when refetching manifest

Previously, we never checked whether the response we get when refetching
is even successful, much less whether it's still coming from an SLO.

Now, if the refetched data is newer, act on it. If it's older, 503.

Closes-Bug: #1837270
Change-Id: I106b94c77da220c762869aa800c31b87c3dffeeb

commit_message:
Remove deprecated "split_branches" config option

This config option was defined in migration_cli module was
deprecated in Newton release and marked to be removed in Ocata.
Now, as we are in Train cycle it's time to remove it finally.

Change-Id: Ic9edf5d01e78d2c47015ad48f8d92c30043cb631

commit_message:
Support TLS deployments with KernelDisableIPv6 enabled

This fixes the nova metadata service to bind to 127.0.0.1 in case
ipv6 is disabled. This is a queens only fix.

Change-Id: I11b2bc84e5a3a7db8d7ca9992accf734a692f51b
Related: rhbz#1703460

commit_message:
Generate locale messages at dev server startup

By default, Horizon doesn't compile localized messages in tox
environment. It leads to silent fail of language change with 'Success'
message. Proposed patch includes compilation of messages to tox runserver
command

Change-Id: I149a622a81a17e9d951c68829349fc70fbb8ed2a

commit_message:
Update api-ref location

The api documentation is now published on docs.openstack.org instead
of developer.openstack.org. Update all links that are changed to the
new location.

Note that redirects will be set up as well but let's point now to the
new location.

For details, see:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-July/007828.html

Change-Id: I300ec4668593b7ce2b44d465ec4b6e302a7c5f76

commit_message:
Add new role parameter NovaLibvirtMemStatsPeriodSeconds

Add role parameter NovaLibvirtMemStatsPeriodSeconds which allows to
set `libvirt/mem_stats_period_seconds` parameter value to
number of seconds to memory usage statistics period, where
zero or negative value mean to disable memory usage statistics.

Default value for the parameter is 10.
Also set the default value to 0 for Real-Time Compute roles.

Conflicts:
      deployment/nova/nova-compute-container-puppet.yaml

Since we dont't have deployment/nova/nova-compute-container-puppet.yaml
in rocky, I have added change related to this file in
puppet/services/nova-compute.yaml file.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/671396/
Change-Id: I8e1a81bc69b4d266755ba3c2a4bf17f37d276fd7
(cherry picked from commit 66c4e23654c6092f5a1afe73ef4f806e24f9da18)
(cherry picked from commit abf34de6c866493bdf282288e6585f7d42da455a)

commit_message:
Add new role parameter NovaLibvirtMemStatsPeriodSeconds

Add role parameter NovaLibvirtMemStatsPeriodSeconds which allows to
set `libvirt/mem_stats_period_seconds` parameter value to
number of seconds to memory usage statistics period, where
zero or negative value mean to disable memory usage statistics.

Default value for the parameter is 10.
Also set the default value to 0 for Real-Time Compute roles.

commit_message:
Update all columns in metrics on an update to refresh TTL

Cassandra Time to Live (TTL) is applied per-column in a
row, and with a default TTL for the table.  The Cassandra
driver appears to have been written with a misunderstanding
that the TTL was per-row, and as a result the update
statements were written to avoid writing all cells.
But that results in some cells in the row not being updated,
and after their TTL expires they are removed, so a metric
query may result in partial data (updated_at set but
metric_id and created_at missing).

This fix changes the statement used when a new measurement
is received to use the same insert statement for the metric
row and thus refresh the TTL for all the columns.

A follow on patch should be created to remove the Update
statements for Measurements, and consider refactoring/removing
the caching model.

Change-Id: I6b7636a52e8bdb2ce8ad97f839acb6184cd58a8b
Story: 2005832
Task: 35872

commit_message:
nova: Remove leftover wsgi file

In I0e9850048cab880ecaece1f87dc5970b0d30fc27 we removed the
nova-placement subpackage to replace it with the placement service,
but forgot to remove the wsgi template.

commit_message:
Add bindep.txt

Without this patch, unit test jobs may fail if the base system does not
have the openLDAP development package installed. This patch ensures that
we don't rely on a fallback bindep file that may or may not be defined
or a base image that may or may not have the required packages
installed.

Change-Id: I5607e7c7307687857f254d9c7bd16af6532ad7e0

[{'created': '2019-07-18 05:33:48.000000000', 'message': 'Add new role parameter NovaLibvirtMemStatsPeriodSeconds

Add role parameter NovaLibvirtMemStatsPeriodSeconds which allows to
set `libvirt/mem_stats_period_seconds` parameter value to
number of seconds to memory usage statistics period, where
zero or negative value mean to disable memory usage statistics.

Default value for the parameter is 10.
Also set the default value to 0 for Real-Time Compute roles.

      roles/ComputeOvsDpdkSriovRT.yaml

Resolved conflict related to ordering of parameters in
RoleParametersDefault section.

commit_message:
Add new role parameter NovaLibvirtMemStatsPeriodSeconds

Add role parameter NovaLibvirtMemStatsPeriodSeconds which allows to
set `libvirt/mem_stats_period_seconds` parameter value to
number of seconds to memory usage statistics period, where
zero or negative value mean to disable memory usage statistics.

Default value for the parameter is 10.
Also set the default value to 0 for Real-Time Compute roles.

Conflicts:
      roles/ComputeOvsDpdkRT.yaml
      roles/ComputeOvsDpdkSriovRT.yaml

Resolved conflict related to ordering of parameters in
RoleParametersDefault section.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/671399/
Change-Id: I8e1a81bc69b4d266755ba3c2a4bf17f37d276fd7
(cherry picked from commit 66c4e23654c6092f5a1afe73ef4f806e24f9da18)
(cherry picked from commit abf34de6c866493bdf282288e6585f7d42da455a)

commit_message:
Start enforcing E125 flake8 directive

Removed E125 (continuation line does not distinguish itself
from next logical line) from the ignore list and fixed all
the indentation issues.  Didn't think it was going to be
close to 100 files when I started.

Change-Id: I0a6f5efec4b7d8d3632dd9dbb43e0ab58af9dff3

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-07-06 22:04:10.000000000', 'message': "Add fullstack tests for update network's segmentation_id

Update of network's segmentation_id was introduced in [1] but
there was no API tests for it.
This patch adds fullstack tests which tests API calls to update
this attribute of vlan networks.

It is done in fullstack tests instead of tempest API test becasuse
this feature is dependend of used backend driver. Currently it is
supported only by openvswitch L2 agent.
In tempest API tests we don't have full controll of what L2 agent
is used to bound ports thus we can't be sure how test will behave.

In fullstack tests we have full control of this so it's easier to
implement such tests.

[1] https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1806052

Change-Id: I5292c67bda2aff08d5302517b5bdf9d8472af8c4

commit_message:
Add fullstack tests for update network's segmentation_id

Update of network's segmentation_id was introduced in [1] but
there was no API tests for it.
This patch adds fullstack tests which tests API calls to update
this attribute of vlan networks.

It is done in fullstack tests instead of tempest API test becasuse
this feature is dependend of used backend driver. Currently it is
supported only by openvswitch L2 agent.
In tempest API tests we don't have full controll of what L2 agent
is used to bound ports thus we can't be sure how test will behave.

In fullstack tests we have full control of this so it's easier to
implement such tests.

[1] https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1806052

Change-Id: I5292c67bda2aff08d5302517b5bdf9d8472af8c4

commit_message:
Upgrade fixes for RabbitMQ and Pacemaker

Override also RabbitMQ long node names (FQDNs) in addition to the
short node names we've been already overriding. This allows RabbitMQ
to start correctly.

Also remove a superfluous when condition in the pacemaker validation
task.

Depends-On: Ia152aed696be15119ba5b75177ef82bc786c4b05
Change-Id: I9eb274071f3fc2258addd9d2f0c1a5406a702573
Closes-Bug: #1832588

commit_message:
Bump the openstackdocstheme extension to 1.20

Some options are now automatically configured by the version 1.20:
- project
- html_last_updated_fmt
- latex_engine
- latex_elements
- version
- release.

Change-Id: Ib5e22f6a5374f05e576bbc00a209209fdb09acad

subject: Initial spec for simple RPC based health checks
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 2394, 'name': 'Adam Spiers', 'email': 'aspiers@suse.com', 'username': 'adam.spiers'}, {'_account_id': 4393, 'name': 'Dan Smith', 'email': 'dms@danplanet.com', 'username': 'danms'}, {'_account_id': 6593, 'name': 'Dirk Mueller', 'email': 'dirk@dmllr.de', 'username': 'dmllr'}, {'_account_id': 6873, 'name': 'Matt Riedemann', 'email': 'mriedem.os@gmail.com', 'username': 'mriedem'}, {'_account_id': 6928, 'name': 'Ben Nemec', 'email': 'openstack@nemebean.com', 'username': 'bnemec'}, {'_account_id': 9963, 'name': 'Jiri Suchomel', 'email': 'jiri.suchomel@suse.com', 'username': 'jsuchome'}, {'_account_id': 12404, 'name': 'Rico Lin', 'email': 'ricolin@ricolky.com', 'username': 'rico.lin'}, {'_account_id': 14070, 'name': 'Eric Fried', 'email': 'openstack@fried.cc', 'username': 'efried'}, {'_account_id': 16222, 'name': 'witek', 'email': 'witold.bedyk@suse.com', 'username': 'witek'}, {'_account_id': 17068, 'name': 'Jean-Philippe Evrard', 'email': 'openstack@a.spamming.party', 'username': 'evrardjp'}, {'_account_id': 18591, 'name': 'Eric Kao', 'email': 'ekcs.openstack@gmail.com', 'username': 'ekcs'}, {'_account_id': 19159, 'name': 'Ifat Afek', 'email': 'ifat.afek@nokia.com', 'username': 'ifat_afek'}, {'_account_id': 21922, 'name': 'Dobroslaw Zybort', 'email': 'dobroslaw.zybort@ts.fujitsu.com', 'username': 'dobrolaw.zybort'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]

[{'account_id': 9963, 'date': '2019-04-18 10:01:39.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-04-23 11:35:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 2394, 'date': '2019-04-26 12:15:15.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 2394, 'date': '2019-04-26 12:17:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-04-26 15:22:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

This seems sane and simple to me, but I'm adding some Nova reviewers who know how to spell RPC."}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2019-04-26 16:11:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 2394, 'date': '2019-04-26 22:35:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

Ah, thanks Dan!  @Jiri, have you tried using ping()?'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-04-28 16:28:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-04-28 16:29:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> (1 comment)

a common approach (if possible and relevant)*'}, {'account_id': 9963, 'date': '2019-04-28 19:38:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

No, I have not tried using ping(), I did not know that it exists.

The question however remains if there's a chance for common approach in various openstack components"}, {'account_id': 2394, 'date': '2019-04-29 04:14:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

@Dan, when you wrote "We already have this built into all services in the form of the ping() method", I guess you were referring to all *nova* RPC services as opposed to all OpenStack RPC services?  If so, maybe there's a case for adding ping() to all other non-nova RPC services which don't already support it.

Also, any chance you could elaborate on the risks you see coming from putting a non-$service component on the private $service rpc bus?  Is it simply the risk of that non-$service component running rogue and destabilising $service?  If we are limiting it to simple RPC liveness probes then I would have thought we could keep this risk very low, but maybe I'm missing something.

Sounds like something we could address this week in the hallway track, maybe.  Thanks!'}, {'account_id': 2394, 'date': '2019-05-07 17:22:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2019-05-07 17:46:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 2394, 'date': '2019-05-07 19:32:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 21922, 'date': '2019-05-09 11:44:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I will paste here some nice considerations from https://github.com/InVisionApp/go-health library README


Container orchestration platforms require that the underlying service(s) expose a "health check" which is used by the platform to determine whether the container is in a good or bad state.

While this can be achieved by simply exposing a /status endpoint that performs synchronous checks against its dependencies (followed by returning a 200 or non-200 status code), it is not optimal for a number of reasons:

    It does not scale
        The more dependencies you add, the longer your health check will take to complete (and potentially cause your service to be killed off by the orchestration platform).
        Depending on the complexity of a given dependency, your check may be fairly involved where it is okay for it to take 30s+ to complete.
    It adds unnecessary load on yours deps or at worst, becomes a DoS target
        Non-malicious scenario
            Thundering herd problem -- in the event of a deployment (or restart, etc.), all of your service containers are likely to have their /status endpoints checked by the orchestration platform as soon as they come up. Depending on the complexity of the checks, running that many simultaneous checks against your dependencies could cause at worst the dependencies to experience problems and at minimum add unnecessary load.
            Security scanners -- if your organization runs periodic security scans, they may hit your /status endpoint and trigger unnecessary dep checks.
        Malicious scenario
            Loading up any basic HTTP benchmarking tool and pointing it at your /status endpoint could choke your dependencies (and potentially your service).

With that said, not everyone needs asynchronous checks. If your service has one dependency (and that is unlikely to change), it is trivial to write a basic, synchronous check and it will probably suffice.'}, {'account_id': 2394, 'date': '2019-05-09 13:33:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> I will paste here some nice considerations from https://github.com/InVisionApp/go-health library README

Thanks for sharing - these considerations serve as valid concerns in general.

> [...]
>
>With that said, not everyone needs asynchronous checks. If your service has one dependency (and that is unlikely to change), it is trivial to write a basic, synchronous check and it will probably suffice.

Yes, exactly.  Those considerations were written in the context of considering the relative merits of synchronous health checks vs. asynchronous ones.  That debate may well become relevant to OpenStack component health checks in the future, but it already unnecessarily delayed any progress in this area for a year or two.  We learned the folly of premature optimization the hard way, and so for now we are targetting simple, lightweight synchronous health checks.  The full history is captured in [this story](https://storyboard.openstack.org/#!/story/2001439) if you are interested.

> Container orchestration platforms require that the underlying service(s) expose a "health check" which is used by the platform to determine whether the container is in a good or bad state.
> 
> While this can be achieved by simply exposing a /status endpoint that performs synchronous checks against its dependencies (followed by returning a 200 or non-200 status code), it is not optimal for a number of reasons:

I appreciate that this go-health library's README is intended to justify the project's existence, but if I was going to nitpick, I'd suggest it slightly toned down its language here: s/is not/may not be/, since the reasons listed below are suppositional generalisations which may or may not apply, depending on the requirements and implementation.

>     It does not scale
>         The more dependencies you add, the longer your health check will take to complete (and potentially cause your service to be killed off by the orchestration platform).

At risk of repeating what you and I have both already said, scaling the number of dependencies may not be required.  If the health check only ever needs to do a small number of simple checks then scaling in this direction is not needed.  The ability to scale with the number of containers and nodes is more important for OpenStack right now.

>         Depending on the complexity of a given dependency, your check may be fairly involved where it is okay for it to take 30s+ to complete.

Implementing long and expensive checks is not considered a significant requirement in OpenStack right now.  If they become required later, then yes we could adopt an async architecture like the one provided by go-health.  But this is a bridge to be crossed when we come to it, and not before.

>     It adds unnecessary load on yours deps or at worst, becomes a DoS target
>         Non-malicious scenario
>             Thundering herd problem -- in the event of a deployment (or restart, etc.), all of your service containers are likely to have their /status endpoints checked by the orchestration platform as soon as they come up. Depending on the complexity of the checks, running that many simultaneous checks against your dependencies could cause at worst the dependencies to experience problems and at minimum add unnecessary load.

Again, this only applies with complex heavyweight checks, which we do not need.  And if we do we will switch them to async.

>             Security scanners -- if your organization runs periodic security scans, they may hit your /status endpoint and trigger unnecessary dep checks.
>         Malicious scenario
>             Loading up any basic HTTP benchmarking tool and pointing it at your /status endpoint could choke your dependencies (and potentially your service).

These shouldn't apply because any endpoints should be firewalled and/or configured to listen only on required interfaces (e.g. localhost) so that they are only accessible by the specific consumers which need them, for example k8s liveness probes which I expect are running on the same host.'}, {'account_id': 21922, 'date': '2019-05-14 08:46:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Thank you for nice reply.'}, {'account_id': 6593, 'date': '2019-06-28 15:44:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Just asking: this is no longer needed, right?'}, {'account_id': 9963, 'date': '2019-07-01 06:49:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Yeah, as I understand this approach has been declined, but I'm not exactly what's the next step. Maybe another PTG discussion?"}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-07-09 13:17:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> Yeah, as I understand this approach has been declined, but I'm not
 > exactly what's the next step. Maybe another PTG discussion?

Investigation about the different approaches discussed for those interested. And documentation of practices <somewhere> (in the case you're raising, it might not be in self-healing sig)."}, {'account_id': 2394, 'date': '2019-07-22 15:11:07.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

IIRC the proposal which seemed to attract the most approval (or at least avoid the most disapproval) was to add a lightweight HTTP endpoint to RPC-only services.  So yeah, someone needs to write a spec for that.  I guess we can abandon this now.'}]

subject: Enable unit tests for py36
messages:
[{'account_id': 10311, 'date': '2019-05-08 14:54:43.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10311, 'date': '2019-05-09 18:12:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Workflow-1

First category of errors:
AttributeError: module 'contextlib' has no attribute 'nested'

Unfortunately, the syntax for equivalent feature is different in py3.  So the version-compatible fallback is to separate and nest the with statements until we move to only py3."}, {'account_id': 10311, 'date': '2019-05-09 21:06:39.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 10311, 'date': '2019-05-09 22:26:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

Finally ran across https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Python3, which has some notes on the contextlib.nested question.'}, {'account_id': 10311, 'date': '2019-05-21 21:31:26.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 10311, 'date': '2019-05-21 21:34:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

This WIP is still a bit of a mess, I started using @mock to resolve the contextlib.nested, then realized a comma separated list of as statements work (as in monasca-persister) so this commit is just for my reference.
Still need to find a cause for the "ModuleNotFoundError: No module named '__builtin__'"'}, {'account_id': 10311, 'date': '2019-05-21 21:34:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 10311, 'date': '2019-05-21 23:16:43.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 10311, 'date': '2019-05-21 23:17:48.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 10311, 'date': '2019-05-21 23:28:31.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 10311, 'date': '2019-06-06 20:24:52.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 10311, 'date': '2019-06-06 20:28:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

(2 comments)

Narrowing down slowly, most of what is left is ugly string/byte encoding differences between py 2 and 3.'}, {'account_id': 10311, 'date': '2019-06-06 23:43:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

@Corey and @zhongshengping - I added you as reviewers so you could be aware that there is work ongoing with Python 3 for Monasca Agent.'}, {'account_id': 10311, 'date': '2019-06-18 04:10:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

@Adrian - Do you have any good ideas for how to deal with the string errors we see in the py3 tests.  Things like 'TypeError: cannot use a string pattern on a bytes-like object'"}, {'account_id': 23735, 'date': '2019-07-09 14:17:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

For errors: 'TypeError: cannot use a string pattern on a bytes-like'

the hostname returned by the hostname -f command in utils.py is bytes while the regex is not. I got the test passing by doing hostname.decode('ascii', 'ignore') for python3 and leave it as it is in python2"}, {'account_id': 23735, 'date': '2019-07-09 14:48:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

diff --git a/tests/detection/test_mon.py b/tests/detection/test_mon.py
index 8ce2776..bbe4fd4 100644
--- a/tests/detection/test_mon.py
+++ b/tests/detection/test_mon.py
@@ -17,6 +17,7 @@ import unittest
 import logging
 import mock
 import psutil
+import sys
 
 from monasca_setup.detection.plugins import mon
 
@@ -185,8 +186,12 @@ class TestMonPersisterDetectionPlugin(unittest.TestCase):
             admin_port=6666
         )
 
+        mod = "builtins"
+        if sys.version_info[0] < 3:
+            mod = "__builtin__"
+
         with mock.patch(
-                "__builtin__.open",
+                mod+".open",
                 mock.mock_open(read_data=yml_cfg)) as mf:
             self._detect(retval=[fake_processes])
             mf.assert_called_once_with('/etc/monasca/persister-config.yml',





diff --git a/tests/detection/test_process_check.py b/tests/detection/test_process_check.py
index 530a388..de50056 100644
--- a/tests/detection/test_process_check.py
+++ b/tests/detection/test_process_check.py
@@ -161,7 +161,7 @@ class TestProcessCheck(unittest.TestCase):
         # the data is translated into a single dictionary.
         fd, temp_path = tempfile.mkstemp(suffix='.yaml', text=True)
         os.write(fd, '---\nprocess_config:\n- process_username: dbadmin\n  dimensions:\n    '
-                 'service: monitoring\n    component: vertica\n')
+                 'service: monitoring\n    component: vertica\n'.encode('ascii', 'ignore'))
         self.proc_plugin.args = {'conf_file_path': temp_path}
         self.proc_plugin._detect()
         result = self.proc_plugin.build_config()


I hope these helps reduce the number of failures :-)'}, {'account_id': 23735, 'date': '2019-07-10 14:23:56.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 23735, 'date': '2019-07-10 15:45:59.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 23735, 'date': '2019-07-11 09:02:58.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 10.'}, {'account_id': 23735, 'date': '2019-07-11 13:05:13.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 11.'}, {'account_id': 26141, 'date': '2019-07-11 13:22:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-05-08 14:54:43.000000000', 'message': 'WIP Enable unit tests for py36

Even though there was a py36 test enabled in the gate, the tox.ini
configuration was not actually invoking the unit tests.  This
change sets up the environment to allow tests to run.

As a result, a number of Python3 errors are uncovered and fixed.

WIP: Still have 65 failures in py36

Change-Id: I62b46a2509c39201ca015ca7c269b2ea70c376c8
Story: 2005047
Task: 29547
'}, {'created': '2019-05-09 21:06:39.000000000', 'message': 'WIP Enable unit tests for py36

Even though there was a py36 test enabled in the gate, the tox.ini
configuration was not actually invoking the unit tests.  This
change sets up the environment to allow tests to run.

As a result, a number of Python3 errors are uncovered and fixed.

Notably:
  Python 3 does not have contextlib.nested, so breaking out layers
  file() is not in Python 3, so use io.open() instead

Some of the refactoring should be revisited after we drop Python 2
support.

WIP: Still have 47 failures in py36

Change-Id: I62b46a2509c39201ca015ca7c269b2ea70c376c8
Story: 2005047
Task: 29547
'}, {'created': '2019-05-21 21:31:26.000000000', 'message': 'WIP Enable unit tests for py36

Even though there was a py36 test enabled in the gate, the tox.ini
configuration was not actually invoking the unit tests.  This
change sets up the environment to allow tests to run.

As a result, a number of Python3 errors are uncovered and fixed.

Notably:
  Python 3 does not have contextlib.nested, so reformatting using ,
  file() is not in Python 3, so use io.open() instead
  Use six.assertCountEqual(self, in tests

Some of the refactoring should be revisited after we drop Python 2
support.

WIP: Still have 26 failures in py36

Change-Id: I62b46a2509c39201ca015ca7c269b2ea70c376c8
Story: 2005047
Task: 29547
'}, {'created': '2019-05-21 23:16:43.000000000', 'message': 'WIP Enable unit tests for py36

safe_decode:

type str. safe_decode does the right thing by making sure string are not

No ascci encoding:

ascii (default for python2).

 the file being opened in binary(wb) mode so python is expecting the
string in bytes.  Changing it to 'w' as there is no binary data written
to the file

support.

commit_message:
Enable unit tests for py36

Even though there was a py36 test enabled in the gate, the tox.ini
configuration was not actually invoking the unit tests.  This
change sets up the environment to allow tests to run.

As a result, a number of Python3 errors are uncovered and fixed.

Notably:
  Python 3 does not have contextlib.nested, so reformatting using ,
  file() is not in Python 3, so use io.open() instead
  Use six.assertCountEqual(self, in tests

safe_decode:
  subprocess.check_output returns in byte encoding, while default text
type str. safe_decode does the right thing by making sure string are not
bytes in python2 and python3

No ascci encoding:
 python3 defaults to UTF-8 encoding, which is merely an extension to
ascii (default for python2).

test_json_plugin.py:
 the file being opened in binary(wb) mode so python is expecting the
string in bytes.

Some of the refactoring should be revisited after we drop Python 2
support.

Change-Id: I62b46a2509c39201ca015ca7c269b2ea70c376c8
Story: 2005047
Task: 29547

commit_message:
Maintenance task: Enhance debug logging

This patch is enhancing the maintenance task debug logs by:

* Logging a summary with the number of failures on each resource type
* Logging the UUID and type of the resource being fixed at that time
* Changing the prefix of the maintenance logs for easy grepping

Closes-Bug: #1837003
Change-Id: I0faa19ef48f2dc5591c0337ae5a0599abc2e4168
Signed-off-by: Lucas Alvares Gomes <lucasagomes@gmail.com>

Seems good to apply at the nova side as well.'}, {'account_id': 24828, 'date': '2019-07-22 03:15:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2019-07-22 08:08:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

openstacksdk is capable of negotiating versions based on what you request (which is how microversions are supposed to be used)'}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2019-07-22 08:15:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 24828, 'date': '2019-07-22 08:34:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> openstacksdk is capable of negotiating versions based on what you
 > request (which is how microversions are supposed to be used)

I know, it's the same thing that ironicclient does, but this change is extending version range that a request could use, so I wonder if we want to avoid changing this, why we don't just use "latest" instead?'}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2019-07-22 08:44:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> I know, it's the same thing that ironicclient does

No, ironicclient doesn't do any automatic negotiation, you have to provide versions explicitly.

> but this change is extending version range that a request could use, so I wonder if we want to avoid changing this, why we don't just use "latest" instead?

Because we don't know if "latest" is compatible with what we have here.'}, {'account_id': 23851, 'date': '2019-07-22 08:55:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 24828, 'date': '2019-07-22 09:02:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> No, ironicclient doesn't do any automatic negotiation, you have to
 > provide versions explicitly.

this automatic negotiation sounds like miracle, maybe worth a digging :P"}, {'account_id': 11076, 'date': '2019-07-22 12:11:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

Thank you Riccardo.'}]

commit_message:
Change how build process treats unbuildable images

We have a list of images which are unbuildable for distro/buildtype/arch
combos. This patch renames it from SKIPPED_IMAGES to UNBUILDABLE_IMAGES
because 'skipped' images is something else in our code.

Now all unbuildable images are marked as such and so are their children.

At the end of build there is information provided about skipped images
(due to --skip-parents or --skip-existing options) and then information
about not buildable images. Both list should only contain entries
related to requested build.

Change-Id: If9b521339f564e483cba03d52e7c4eba271821a5

[{'created': '2019-06-24 13:13:19.000000000', 'message': 'Issue blocking ACK for RPC requests from the consumer thread

The patch for https://review.openstack.org/#/c/436958/ fixed a
threading problem by moving the ack back to the polling
thread. However the RPC server expects to catch any failures of the
ACK and abort the request.  This patch adds the ACK error handling
back to the polling thread.

This patch is based heavily off the original work done by Mehdi
Abaakouk (sileht).

Change-Id: I708c3d6676b974d8daac6817c15f596cdf35817b
Closes-Bug: #1695746
(cherry picked from commit 26b0be585a0b681d011edcb688750770bcdae199)
'}]
commit_message:
Issue blocking ACK for RPC requests from the consumer thread

The patch for https://review.openstack.org/#/c/436958/ fixed a
threading problem by moving the ack back to the polling
thread. However the RPC server expects to catch any failures of the
ACK and abort the request.  This patch adds the ACK error handling
back to the polling thread.

This patch is based heavily off the original work done by Mehdi
Abaakouk (sileht).

Change-Id: I708c3d6676b974d8daac6817c15f596cdf35817b
Closes-Bug: #1695746
(cherry picked from commit 26b0be585a0b681d011edcb688750770bcdae199)

commit_message:
Install gettext for translation jobs

Add install of gettext to prepare-zanata-client role so that projects
don't need to add it to their bindep.txt file.
gettext is essential for the role to work.

For consistency capitalize all names of tasks in the file.

Change-Id: Ic36534c4edfbb086f5bcc66ab657107552ba92de

commit_message:
Remove publish-openstack-manuals-developer-lang

We don't need this job anymore since content is moved to
openstack-manuals, remove it.

Remove also the now unused translation job template from api-site.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/671115
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/671124
Change-Id: I11fc113208cb38e76ef1603bc5a71de494c5b70f
