Given that feature proposal freeze is next week do we actually think we have enough time for implementation if we accept this?"}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2019-01-28 15:13:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

> > > I'd like to have that in a public forum if possible. I thought
 > we
 > > > discussed a note to the mailing list at the last meeting?
 > >
 > > Yes I think that's what we discussed, I think either you as PTL
 > or
 > > Kristi as spec owner should initiate that request on the mailing
 > > list.
 > 
 > Given that feature proposal freeze is next week do we actually
 > think we have enough time for implementation if we accept this?

I prefer the request for an exception be submitted by the person owning the specification, only because it doesn't seem like PTLs are approving specification exceptions they propose themselves (though we don't have a policy against that at all - just personal preference).

I'll let Kristi weigh-in on the work required and time commitments because I do agree we're running a little tight on time."}, {'account_id': 8482, 'date': '2019-02-15 09:55:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review-2

commit_message:
Expiring Group Membership Through Mapping Rules

Add federated users to the groups that they receive from the mapping rules.
This membership is only carried by the token and not persisted in the
database. The membership expires, but can be renewed when the user
authenticates with the same group.

Partial-Bug: 1809116

Change-Id: If376a1ce18f9b628f429f3cac957c76dacd00a34

commit_message:
Bump the openstackdocstheme extension to 1.20

Some options are now automatically configured by the version 1.20:
- project
- html_last_updated_fmt
- latex_engine
- latex_elements
- version
- release.

Change-Id: I3a5c7e115d0c4f52b015d0d55eb09c9836cd2fe7

commit_message:
Cleanup unused Postgres config values

This patch is part of an effort to cleanup the values.yaml file for
Postgres, which has gotten messy since the introduction of Patroni. This
patch specifically removes unused configuration values which were
causing unnecessary bloat and complexity.

Change-Id: I96180fd9c91200ba7558e58bd503b4ef9ebc183e

commit_message:
Convert dynamic includes to static imports

When task/role files are included using include_tasks, tags are not
passed to the included tasks. As a result, tags like neutron-config
do not have the intended effect. This patch changes include_tasks
to import_tasks for all cases where dynamic vars or loops are not used
so that tags are properly handled.

Reference -
https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/user_guide/playbooks_reuse.html
https://bugs.launchpad.net/openstack-ansible/+bug/1815043

Change-Id: I39ffc73bb12ba93432251d91def78031b2a2b1e9

Convert dynamic includes to static imports

When task/role files are included using include_tasks, tags are not
passed to the included tasks. As a result, tags like swift-config
do not have the intended effect. This patch changes include_tasks
to import_tasks for all cases where dynamic vars or loops are not used
so that tags are properly handled.

commit_message:
Convert dynamic includes to static imports

When task/role files are included using include_tasks, tags are not
passed to the included tasks. As a result, tags like trove-config
do not have the intended effect. This patch changes include_tasks
to import_tasks for all cases where dynamic vars or loops are not used
so that tags are properly handled.

Reference -
https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/user_guide/playbooks_reuse.html
https://bugs.launchpad.net/openstack-ansible/+bug/1815043

Change-Id: I754049a0e37daadddf1fa52a3b651284ee02b27e

reviewers: [{'_account_id': 7, 'name': 'Jay Pipes', 'email': 'jaypipes@gmail.com', 'username': 'jaypipes'}, {'_account_id': 4393, 'name': 'Dan Smith', 'email': 'dms@danplanet.com', 'username': 'danms'}, {'_account_id': 5754, 'name': 'Alex Xu', 'email': 'hejie.xu@intel.com', 'username': 'xuhj'}, {'_account_id': 7166, 'name': 'Sylvain Bauza', 'email': 'sbauza@redhat.com', 'username': 'sbauza'}, {'_account_id': 8864, 'name': 'Artom Lifshitz', 'email': 'alifshit@redhat.com', 'username': 'artom'}, {'_account_id': 9708, 'name': 'Balazs Gibizer', 'display_name': 'gibi', 'email': 'gibizer@gmail.com', 'username': 'gibi'}, {'_account_id': 10608, 'name': 'Matthew Edmonds', 'email': 'edmondsw@us.ibm.com', 'username': 'edmondsw'}, {'_account_id': 11564, 'name': 'Chris Dent', 'email': 'cdent@anticdent.org', 'username': 'chdent'}, {'_account_id': 11604, 'name': 'sean mooney', 'email': 'smooney@redhat.com', 'username': 'sean-k-mooney'}, {'_account_id': 14070, 'name': 'Eric Fried', 'email': 'openstack@fried.cc', 'username': 'efried'}, {'_account_id': 21672, 'name': 'Sundar Nadathur', 'email': 'sundar.nadathur@intel.com', 'username': 'nsundar'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 26458, 'name': 'Brin Zhang', 'email': 'zhangbailin@inspur.com', 'username': 'zhangbailin'}, {'_account_id': 27961, 'name': 'Konstantinos Samaras-Tsakiris', 'email': 'konstantinos.samaras-tsakiris@cern.ch', 'username': 'kosamara'}, {'_account_id': 29334, 'name': 'Dakshina Ilangovan', 'email': 'dakshina.ilangovan@intel.com', 'username': 'dakshinai'}, {'_account_id': 29745, 'name': 'Dustin Cowles', 'email': 'cowlesd@gmail.com', 'username': 'dustinc', 'status': 'inactive'}, {'_account_id': 30001, 'name': 'Ivens Zambrano', 'email': 'ivens.zambrano@intel.com', 'username': 'IvensZambrano'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-10-22 20:16:31.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 5754, 'date': '2018-10-23 13:34:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(4 comments)

I like this feature, some questions.'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-10-23 20:00:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(2 comments)

Need to think about this harder, but meandering comment within about my first reaction.'}, {'account_id': 7166, 'date': '2018-10-24 10:37:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(8 comments)

While I agree with the objective, I think we shouldn't block other specs because of this spec.

Deprecating config options is simple, so we could just do something like :
- create the YAML file
- for a specific usecase (say PCI passthrough), deprecate the option and add the YAML needed version
- next cycle, remove the deprecated option

That way, it wouldn't really block the other specs.

Also, we really need to think about upgrades, FFU and reshape in this spec."}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-10-24 23:03:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

(12 comments)

> While I agree with the objective, I think we shouldn't block other specs because of this spec.

Not sure what gave you the impression that we would be doing that.

> Deprecating config options is simple, so we could just do something like :
> 
> create the YAML file
> for a specific usecase (say PCI passthrough), deprecate the option and add the YAML needed version
> next cycle, remove the deprecated option
> That way, it wouldn't really block the other specs.

Yes, that's exactly how I would expect things to go. Otherwise we would be holding up nearly every feature in the queue, which is clearly not realistic.

> Also, we really need to think about upgrades, FFU and reshape in this spec.

No, we do not. The work outlined in this spec is deliberately narrowly scoped to defining the format of the file. The code product is a schema/parser/validator/sample. The file could be used in a million ways by a million features in this and future cycles. We cannot and should not attempt to design all of them now. The Use Cases section describes a few of the features we know about that *might* use this at *some* point, and we've designed the file with those in mind. But this document was born in part out of complaints that the spec that attempted to design the file and one (just one) use case for it was too long [1].

Now, I don't think it's unreasonable for us to write up at least one spec that will depend on this work. I intend to modify the device-placement-model spec to that end. That spec will have to address upgrade concerns for migrating from [pci]passthrough_whitelist. And it's not out of the question that iterating on that spec will necessitate changes to the file format outlined here. That's fine, and it's why we define versioning.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/591037/8/specs/stein/approved/device-placement-model.rst@234"}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-12-04 18:33:37.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-12-04 23:56:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

(7 comments)

Code is at [1]. Other than fleshing out the tests, that's truly all that will be involved with this blueprint.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/622622/"}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2019-01-10 02:16:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(5 comments)

just saving comments... this is a long one.'}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2019-01-10 03:32:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-01-12 21:46:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(4 comments)'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2019-01-14 19:32:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 29334, 'date': '2019-05-31 08:48:49.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-05-31 18:25:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Thanks for picking this up, Dakshina.

Somewhere (possibly in this spec, possibly in a dependent spec) we should have a discussion of how nova will consume the file.'}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2019-06-04 12:11:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(18 comments)'}, {'account_id': 29334, 'date': '2019-06-06 12:12:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(7 comments)'}, {'account_id': 29334, 'date': '2019-06-06 12:17:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> (7 comments)

@Eric please help clarify, the only consumer of concern is here is the virt driver,

so question is if we keep the file generic or hypervisor specific, for instance to include pci information for libvirt'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-06-06 16:58:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

(22 comments)

Thanks for the thorough look, gibi.

Summary of what I think needs to be done with this spec:
- Explicitly state that the file is to be consumed exclusively by nova-compute, and more specifically virt drivers, which will a) definitely use it in update_provider_tree to effect changes in placement representations of things; and b) possibly use it in instance lifecycle operations e.g. to map "provider" to "real thing on system".
- Enumerate some *specific* use cases we want to support initially via ^, with samples of what the file looks like for them (this exists at the bottom of the doc; move it closer to the top). For the first pass, this might be limited to "add inventory of new resource classes on providers that already exist" and "add or remove traits on providers that already exist", which would both feed into the specific use cases for RMD (LLC, p-state). We can extend later to handle VGPU, generic PCI passthrough, adding new nested providers, removing providers, etc.
- Make "real thing on system" a freeform subsection of "identification".
- Simplify, simplify, simplify the schema. Remove 'owner', 'passthrough', 'rename', the real-thing-on-system bits of 'identification', etc. Keep only what's needed for the specific use cases noted above.'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2019-06-12 16:01:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

(10 comments)

FWIW, I think that what is described here gives the operator too much power. I get that we _can_ provide a full DSL for ultimate translation of every possible thing that u-p-t is going to do, but that doesn't mean we should. I would much prefer to lay out just the sorts of things we want to override and support those, but with a syntax/schema that allows us to grow in the future. Patching random bits of inventory when the average operator will *never* understand the full gravity of what they're doing makes no sense to me. Allowing them to remove traits from the provider that has no purpose other than to break nova in subtle ways is more harmful than useful, IMHO.

Story time...

I remember a bug I was working on, where someone ended up with inconsistent data in the database. I was chasing the root cause with them for a long time, trying to figure out how they could have one object that referenced an instance that didn't exist when our DB schema clearly had a constraint requiring it. We finally realized that, months ago, they had followed instructions from "an expert" in another bug, related to something mundane. Those instructions were to disable constraint checking in mysql, do a few update queries (which in themselves were wrong) and then re-enable the constraint checking. On a live system. The few minutes those were disabled completely effed their production database and caused a majorly expensive bug-chasing exercise upstream where I thought we had major problems.

Now, I know we can't prevent people from cutting off their own hands, or disabling constraint checking in the database, but we *can* choose what tools to provide them (which will be seen as blessed) and some of this seems to be a little too powerful to me.'}, {'account_id': 29334, 'date': '2019-06-19 11:15:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(9 comments)'}, {'account_id': 29334, 'date': '2019-06-19 11:19:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Thank you for the discussion.

Few opens before I publish the simplified version. Hopefully we could close on the open comments too.

1. When we identify multiple rps, wouldn't we repeat the customization on each compute node, if the same file is deployed?
2. Any specific reason behind having minor version for file (no structural changes e.t.c?)? Would we need a nova config to say minimum supported version since with every major version bump, we need code changes."}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-06-19 18:01:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

(11 comments)

> 1. When we identify multiple rps, wouldn't we repeat the customization on each compute node, if the same file is deployed?

Not sure I understand the question. I've noted inline that we should support a $COMPUTE_HOST meta-uuid, which would conceivably allow you to deploy the actual same file to multiple compute hosts. But otherwise I would assume the file would be templated and customized per host, yeah?

> 2. Any specific reason behind having minor version for file (no structural changes e.t.c?)? Would we need a nova config to say minimum supported version since with every major version bump, we need code changes.

Overall I like $major for breaking changes and $minor for backward-compatible changes, even if it's just for human comprehensibility. And why not? It's not like it's particularly harder than a single version number. And the nova compat/upgrade/lockstepping is the same either way. But I'm not going to fall on my sword over this issue."}, {'account_id': 29334, 'date': '2019-06-21 08:43:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(7 comments)'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-06-24 16:52:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(4 comments)'}, {'account_id': 29334, 'date': '2019-06-28 10:40:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 29334, 'date': '2019-06-28 10:45:26.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-06-28 22:04:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

(50 comments)

Dramatic reduction in size on this iteration \o/

More work to do.

I've identified a number of other bits that need to be trimmed.

But one major thing needs to be added: the description of how this is going to be consumed by Nova."}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-06-28 22:08:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 29334, 'date': '2019-07-03 13:50:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(6 comments)'}, {'account_id': 29334, 'date': '2019-07-03 14:00:39.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 29334, 'date': '2019-07-03 14:36:05.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 29334, 'date': '2019-07-03 14:43:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

Old changes that were removed

Removed device passthrough section
Removed Collab Tree Mgmt section - nova only
Removed sharing providers?
Removed pci/trait/aggregate identification
Removed ownership section
Removed name/uuid customization
Removed remove inventory customization
Removed usecases not corresponding to current schema features
Removed support for create new provider/child providers

Few closing questions on this patch
1. Describe how file is consumed by nova compute - Code snippet? Can this code be generalized to Nova? Not sure why this has to be specific to virt driver implementations. Are we talking about spawn() changes?
2. Create and customize child provider in schema, Remove NUMA inventory from root and introduce in child provider - LLC usecase. Need thoughts.
3. Customization inventory/trait involving non-native resources. Is it ok to introduce remove and rename?
4. TBD: LLC and P-state examples in schema format.'}, {'account_id': 29745, 'date': '2019-07-03 16:34:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Code-Review-1

(6 comments)'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-07-03 19:55:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: Code-Review-1

(22 comments)

Thanks Dakshina, this is coming together very nicely and is really close now I think.

> 1. Describe how file is consumed by nova compute - Code snippet?

I think what you have in the document is probably enough. I may be interpolating a lot because I'm familiar, though, so let's get other reviewers to weigh in.

> Can this code be generalized to Nova? Not sure why this has to be specific to virt driver implementations. Are we talking about spawn() changes?

Not spawn changes... yet. spawn would have to be able to figure out physical resources on the system and know what to do with them. That's a direction we're heading with this, e.g. to replace [pci]passthrough_whitelist and [pci]alias. But we're not doing it for this pass.

It's virt driver specific because update_provider_tree is virt driver specific; and update_provider_tree is the source of truth for Placement's representation of the compute node.

But (as mentioned inline) we may at this stage be able to do the loading/parsing and schema validation in common code, and pass the processed object to the virt driver. We can discuss that further, but (as mentioned inline) it may be okay to defer those details to implementation time.

> 2. Create and customize child provider in schema, Remove NUMA inventory from root and introduce in child provider - LLC usecase. Need thoughts.

See response inline. TL;DR: I can be convinced that we should reinstate the ability to create child providers for purposes of grouping, as long as we don't try to claim any ability to use them for NUMA affinity yet.

> 3. Customization inventory/trait involving non-native resources. Is it ok to introduce remove and rename?

Responses inline: these add complexity, and we don't need them yet, so let's leave them out.

> 4. TBD: LLC and P-state examples in schema format.

Yes please.

Summary of the main changes I'm looking for in the next rev:
- Reinstate ability to create child providers, if you are convinced the benefit outweighs the cost.
- Examples per #4 above.
- Clean up formatting (tabs, trailing whitespace, long lines)."}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2019-07-04 11:19:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Code-Review-1

(8 comments)

Some formatting and relatively minor comments within. Some questions out here which may have been discussed on earlier revisions, sorry if I missed them:

* It's hard to grok from this spec how this is supposed to work. The format requires a uuid of a resource provider or $COMPUTE_HOST. If the latter is used the added inventory and traits are always on the compute node. If the former is used a) what is discovering those uuids, did something else already create the providers associated with those uuids? b) those providers are presumably children of $COMPUTE_HOST who/what is managing that topology?

* Given the above, it seems the extra providers need to already exist, somehow, and what this file is doing is saying to the virt driver: "If you stumble across a provider in your provider tree with an identifier in this file, I want it updated to have attributes as described by the file".

The above doesn't really impact on the format of the file (which seems fine for the limited use cases described) but it does impact on judging whether having the file at all is the best fit for purpose, so is useful info.

(The -1 is mostly for the whitespace issues)'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-07-08 16:33:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

Some formatting and relatively minor comments within. Some questions out here which may have been discussed on earlier revisions, sorry if I missed them:

It's hard to grok from this spec how this is supposed to work. The format requires a uuid of a resource provider or $COMPUTE_HOST. If the latter is used the added inventory and traits are always on the compute node. If the former is used a) what is discovering those uuids, did something else already create the providers associated with those uuids? b) those providers are presumably children of $COMPUTE_HOST who/what is managing that topology?
Given the above, it seems the extra providers need to already exist, somehow, and what this file is doing is saying to the virt driver: "If you stumble across a provider in your provider tree with an identifier in this file, I want it updated to have attributes as described by the file".
The above doesn't really impact on the format of the file (which seems fine for the limited use cases described) but it does impact on judging whether having the file at all is the best fit for purpose, so is useful info.

@Chris, Currently, this spec does not support a use-case that needs creation of resource providers using the file. Having said this, if not for compute resource provider (at the root), the sys-admin or supporting external process should identify and provide the UUID of a child rp (that already exists).'}, {'account_id': 29334, 'date': '2019-07-10 14:15:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

PS4, Line 194:

No, I mean something so that whatever agent is doing the assignment of *physical* resources can know which physical resource to use based on the placement allocation.

For example if we were managing PCI devices, we need some way to tie the placement resources in a provider inventory to the real devices on the system. That's what the PCI address business was about in previous revs of this spec.

We're not trying to manage PCI devices specifically right now - but on the other hand we're not explicitly restricting what can be supported either. The question is: do our known use cases require the ability to map specific *physical* resources from a specific resource provider inventory? And if so, does that mapping require any kind of special affordance in this file?

For now, I'm going to say no, because you can do this association with custom traits -- which we're already supporting via this file.

@Eric, I'm not sure if I understand the argument well, but If you are talking about what the agent (like RMD) or virt-driver (overrides in future), should do next to manage the resources reported from file, 

This should be per use-case and can be translated from flavor/flavor-extra specs?

Not sure if any identification should come from the file."}, {'account_id': 29334, 'date': '2019-07-10 14:49:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

PS4, Line 109:
I sympathize with the problem here. I'm trying to find every possible way to reduce the scope of this work for the current release.

The max_unit trick is clever, but a) it still won't prevent you from getting allocations that can only be satisfied by spanning multiple NUMA nodes; and 

b) it easily breaks when more than one isolated guest NUMA node is requested. (The max_unit is enforced for the whole allocation, not per request group.)

>>> If we request cores from more the one NUMA, we need to ensure, LLC allocations from each of those NUMA. This goes back to our problem of reporting LLC per NUMA in placement

We're going to have to deal with reshaping regardless of whether the resources start off on the compute node RP or nested RPs, so that aspect is moot.

Rejecting a scheduling request because we can't allocate the requested amount of LLC from a single NUMA node is an improvement (though far from a complete solution since it's still possible to allocate from the *wrong* NUMA node(s)). 

>>> We must get the specific NUMA information at the time of scheduling

So it's really just a question of whether that improvement is worth the added complexity of supporting creation of new providers at this time.

If we decide the answer is yes, the use case should be phrased in terms of the ability to group/split resources to reflect how they exist on the host, *not* in terms of topology/affinity, because we absolutely have no way to affect that yet.

>>> Few possibilities, please help evaluate

1. Support flavor to extend to numa_llc? Can you clarify how NUMA based CPUs and memory is modeled in placement today?

$ openstack flavor set m1.large --property hw:numa_nodes=2
$ openstack flavor set m1.large \  # configure guest node 0
  --property hw:numa_cpus.0=0,1 \
  --property hw:numa_mem.0=2048
$ openstack flavor set m1.large \  # configure guest node 1
  --property hw:numa_cpus.1=2,3,4,5 \
  --property hw:numa_mem.1=4096

2. If we create child rps for LLC, they should still be associated with cores that can use them. Which means moving core information from compute rp to child rps (to later apply granular resource requests to co-locate LLC and CPU cores). Not sure how can we can model LLC without considering topology."}, {'account_id': 29334, 'date': '2019-07-10 14:52:06.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2019-07-10 15:02:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

No. You can either a) depend on the PCPU blueprint, and make PCPUs p-state capable, but still only have all p-state or all non p-state CPUs in your VM; or b) depend on the PCPU-and-VCPU-in-one-VM spec to lift that limitation.'}, {'account_id': 30001, 'date': '2019-07-16 16:21:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

The particular "P-States capable" example is not applicable, all the cores in the CPU will be P-States capable, then you can use system deployment tool or the resource manager to enable or disable it on specific cores.
However, for SST-BF (base frequency split) it would make sense. I think that could be a future discussion.'}, {'account_id': 30001, 'date': '2019-07-16 17:58:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

[1]https://docs.openstack.org/placement/latest/placement-api-microversion-history.html#support-same-subtree-queryparam-on-get-allocation-candidates'}, {'account_id': 29334, 'date': '2019-07-17 08:14:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

It seems like we can address a complex problem on the same lines as SST-BF proposal but it could be a separate discussion - also leading to new specs.

1. Enabling LLC support

The current apporach as Eric suggested is to let the LLC be modeled in the root resource provider. Considering that we have multiple LLC, we can live with a max=size of single LLC, total=sum of size of all LLC approach. This is not clean but we can late fail the spawn for the following cases

A. CPU pinning information not available to choose the right NUMA
B. Not enough cache on the desired NUMA (if cores are on different NUMA or insufficient LLC)
C. Any other fragmentation that implies incorrect total

In future, we could extend NUMATopologyFilter and virt-driver to support LLC as a NUMA bound resource as described in [1]

Is this a direction for NUMA bound resources or is something better coming up?

2. P-state usecases

One other possibility is to expose a subset of cores as P-state enabled/disabled as dictated by a node policy(that can also work in conjunction with SST-BF tiers as determined by the virt driver [2])

This will also require changes to virt-driver, NUMATopologyFilter and creation of new child providers.

Until the required changes are available, we may not need the create child provider capability.

Hence, we are keeping it simple at this point to simply express if a compute node supports P-state/not and leave it upto virt-driver or RMD understanding extra-specs to enable/disable.

[1]
http://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/juno/implemented/virt-driver-numa-placement.html

[2] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/649882/3/specs/train/approved/separate-vcpu-into-different-priority-pool.rst'}, {'account_id': 29334, 'date': '2019-07-17 08:29:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

Facing server issues.

Example here - until then

.. code-block:: yaml

  meta:
    schema_version: 1.0

  providers:
    - identification:	
        uuid: $COMPUTE_HOST    
      customization:
          inventories:
              ensure:
                  $resource_class:
                      # Describing LLC on this compute node
		      # max_unit indicates maximum size of single LLC
		      # total indicates sum of sizes of all LLC
                      total: 22
                      reserved: 2
                      min_unit: 1
                      max_unit: 11
                      step_size: 1
                      allocation_ratio: 1 
          traits:
              ensure:
		  # Describing that this compute node enables support for
		  # P-state control
                  - CUSTOM_P_STATE_ENABLED'}, {'account_id': 29334, 'date': '2019-07-17 15:55:47.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 10.'}, {'account_id': 29334, 'date': '2019-07-17 15:57:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

Yes

> This is not clean but we can late fail the spawn for the following cases

To be clear, "we" can't late fail the spawn. NUMATopologyFilter can do so for

> A. CPU pinning information not available to choose the right NUMA

but RMD-wise you'll just have to live with

> B. Not enough cache on the desired NUMA (if cores are on different NUMA or insufficient LLC)
> C. Any other fragmentation that implies incorrect total

> In future, we could extend NUMATopologyFilter and virt-driver to support LLC as a NUMA bound resource as described in [1]
> 
> Is this a direction for NUMA bound resources or is something better coming up?

Um, yeah, that's a Juno spec. "Something better" is going to be centering around placement. But I still don't see a way for out-of-band efforts like RMD to extend NUMATopologyFilter and/or virt drivers.

> Hence, we are keeping it simple at this point to simply express if a compute node supports P-state/not and leave it upto virt-driver or RMD understanding extra-specs to enable/disable.

Dan identified a couple of edits that need to be made, but IMO the intent & direction is clear and the edits could be done in a fup for the sake of getting this moving, so re+1ing.

> @Eric, What's the Juno spec?

I was referring to this statement of yours:

> In future, we could extend NUMATopologyFilter and virt-driver to support LLC as a NUMA bound resource as described in [1]
<snip>
> [1]
http://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/juno/implemented/virt-driver-numa-placement.html

> Unless we want to support static provisioning in general for LLC/P-state resources and things like RMD can extend the flavor for other dynamic features.

I don't understand this sentence. The only thing this spec helps you do is static provisioning by extending the flavor. If you want RMD to read random new extra specs out of the flavor and use them to do dynamic things to the instance, that's fine, but it has nothing to do with this spec.

> Regarding late fail, in situations A, B an C, where RMD can not satisfy the LLC allocation request, what is the best way to error the VM creation or else it would be inconsistent to have the VM running without the flavor requirements met (Max thing RMD would do is give the VM available cache ways from default pool - leftovers)

Yes, leftovers, until we have more granular reporting/scheduling/allocation of NUMA nodes.

The only thing you could conceivably do (and some might consider this a hack) is implement a scheduler filter that talks to RMD on the compute to find out if the cache allocations can be satisfied correctly."}, {'account_id': 29334, 'date': '2019-07-17 23:03:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

Correct, nothing to do with this spec. What I was saying is, for just static provisioning of new NUMA bound resources, if we can extend the NUMATopologyFilter, but that can be a new spec in itself.

To create a custom scheduler filter - especially for LLC (probably avoid communication to RMD), do we need a new spec? I believe not? We could probably minimize failures.

 > correctly."}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-07-18 00:49:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11:

'}, {'created': '2019-07-03 14:00:39.000000000', 'message': "Spec: Provider config YAML file

This is a proposal to configure resource provider visibility, ownership,
inventory, trait, and aggregate settings using a standardized YAML file format.

.. note:: This work is derived from `Jay's Rocky provider-config-file
          proposal`_ and `Konstantinos's device-placement-model spec`_ (which
          is derived from `Eric's device-passthrough spec`_), but differs in
          several substantive ways.

.. note:: This work is influenced by requirements to Nova to support non
          native compute resources that are managed by Resource Management
		  Daemon for finer grain control. PTG discussion notes available at
		  `Resource Management Daemon_PTG Summary`_

.. note:: We currently limit the ownership and consumption of the provider
          config YAML as described by the file format to Nova only.

.. note:: The provider config will currently only accept placement overrides
          to create and manage inventories and traits for resources not
		  natively managed by the Nova virt driver.

.. note:: This is intended to define a *framework* for currently active
		  usecases. Subsequent features can define the semantics by which the
		  framework can be used by consumers(besides Nova) or enhanced to
		  satisfy particular use cases.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/550244/2/specs/rocky/approved/provider-config-file.rst
[2] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/591037/8/specs/stein/approved/device-placement-model.rst
[3] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/579359/10/doc/source/specs/rocky/device-passthrough.rst
[4] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-May/005809.html

Change-Id: I3b3f3227bc8c0c6a1057122a3014131b1baf72a6
blueprint: provider-config-file
Signed-off-by: dakshinai <dakshina.ilangovan@intel.com>

commit_message:
Spec: Provider config YAML file

This is a proposal to configure resource provider visibility, ownership,
inventory, trait, and aggregate settings using a standardized YAML file format.

.. note:: This work is derived from `Jay's Rocky provider-config-file
          proposal`_ and `Konstantinos's device-placement-model spec`_ (which
          is derived from `Eric's device-passthrough spec`_), but differs in
          several substantive ways.

.. note:: This work is influenced by requirements to Nova to support non
          native compute resources that are managed by Resource Management
          Daemon for finer grain control. PTG discussion notes available at
	  `Resource Management Daemon_PTG Summary`_

.. note:: We currently limit the ownership and consumption of the provider
          config YAML as described by the file format to Nova only.

.. note:: The provider config will currently only accept placement overrides
          to create and manage inventories and traits for resources not
	  natively managed by the Nova virt driver.

.. note:: This is intended to define a *framework* for currently active
          usecases. Subsequent features can define the semantics by which the
	  framework can be used by consumers(besides Nova) or enhanced to
          satisfy particular use cases.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/550244/2/specs/rocky/approved/provider-config-file.rst
[2] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/591037/8/specs/stein/approved/device-placement-model.rst
[3] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/579359/10/doc/source/specs/rocky/device-passthrough.rst
[4] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-May/005809.html

Change-Id: I3b3f3227bc8c0c6a1057122a3014131b1baf72a6
blueprint: provider-config-file
Signed-off-by: dakshinai <dakshina.ilangovan@intel.com>

commit_message:
Convert dynamic includes to static imports

When task/role files are included using include_tasks, tags are not
passed to the included tasks. As a result, tags like neutron-config
do not have the intended effect. This patch changes include_tasks
to import_tasks for all cases where dynamic vars or loops are not used
so that tags are properly handled.

Reference -
https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/user_guide/playbooks_reuse.html
https://bugs.launchpad.net/openstack-ansible/+bug/1815043

Change-Id: I7dd8734b66a9cb704a69b3a76d7b3f8c52cbf6f0

commit_message:
sync: use proposal-bot + gerrit ssh API to pull projects

With the transition to OpenDev, we cannot rely on the old URLs
and this is a much cleaner solution that leverages the proposa-bot
user to get all the information we need.

Change-Id: Ie5dae335c12e178928186637b7b73f97c6a694ab

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-03-24 21:58:20.000000000', 'message': 'Replace openstack.org git:// URLs with https://

This is a mechanically generated change to replace openstack.org
git:// URLs with https:// equivalents.

This is in aid of a planned future move of the git hosting
infrastructure to a self-hosted instance of gitea (https://gitea.io),
which does not support the git wire protocol at this stage.

This update should result in no functional change.

For more information see the thread at

 http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-March/003825.html

Change-Id: I451e4535b028b18dc9358701b5f3b3317daf2479
'}]
commit_message:
Replace openstack.org git:// URLs with https://

This is a mechanically generated change to replace openstack.org
git:// URLs with https:// equivalents.

This is in aid of a planned future move of the git hosting
infrastructure to a self-hosted instance of gitea (https://gitea.io),
which does not support the git wire protocol at this stage.

This update should result in no functional change.

For more information see the thread at

 http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-March/003825.html

Change-Id: I451e4535b028b18dc9358701b5f3b3317daf2479

commit_message:
Update Neutron grafana dashboard

Recently there was couple of changes in Neutron CI jobs config:

- [1] added new job "tempest-integrated-networking",
- [2] removed tempest-full and tempest-full-py3 jobs - those jobs are
  replaced with "tempest-integrated-networking" job,
- [3] added new non-voting job:
  tripleo-ci-centos-7-scenario007-standalone

This patch reflects above changes in Neutron Grafana dashboard.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/669815/
[2] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/670717/
[3] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/670029/

Change-Id: I01320361e6dc05b43f46451ef128116eb1aa3aa6

commit_message:
Nagios: Add elasticsearch python clients to image

This adds the elasticsearch and elasticsearch-dsl python client
packages to the Nagios image, so that they can be used to support
plugins and scripts for querying Elasticsearch directly

Change-Id: Ic235bf1409ee58aa49d299f07c27dc166b3b8c1f
Signed-off-by: Steve Wilkerson <sw5822@att.com>

commit_message:
Followup for provider config file spec

Addresses the following on the provider-config-file spec:

- Adds a caution about how ironic nodes will be affected when they move
  from one compute host to another.
- Adds an implementation note for the schema since it was in my head.

Change-Id: Iea385d122675a341e0374223992e9a689049d04b
Blueprint: provider-config-file

commit_message:
proposal: add sync for doc/* in openstack-ansible

We have started to maintain some of the items inside doc/* to be
sync'd such as requirements to build docs, this patch adds it.

Change-Id: I73c32ea17a9fb0f6d0ba1887f8618aa508ba63c5

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-07-19 12:11:19.000000000', 'message': 'Use systemd-journald instead of log files

This patch aims to migrate service from usage of regular syslog files
to journald.
By this we mean dropping rsyslog client installation. log_address is set
by default to /dev/log, which is served by journald.

Change-Id: I6dd0d77004394bb1ad674b53538b0679b056bb0f
'}]
commit_message:
Use systemd-journald instead of log files

This patch aims to migrate service from usage of regular syslog files
to journald.
By this we mean dropping rsyslog client installation. log_address is set
by default to /dev/log, which is served by journald.

Change-Id: I6dd0d77004394bb1ad674b53538b0679b056bb0f

(cherry picked from commit a0b9f90a2eefb7d65a72503a0a970451efda1d04)
(cherry picked from commit 76356dc4f2a87cc8035a8b420f7886b5c7b24c82)

commit_message:
Add a suffix for tmpwatch

Change 641608 introduces tmpwatch into logrotate-crond container.
However, LogrotatePurgeAfterDays parameter is parsed in hours because
there is no suffix to the value. This commit adds a suffix, 'd' to the
value.

Closes-Bug: #1836848
Change-Id: I5e2c92a60f73b75a144228fd13ac31fff990a038
(cherry picked from commit a0b9f90a2eefb7d65a72503a0a970451efda1d04)
(cherry picked from commit 76356dc4f2a87cc8035a8b420f7886b5c7b24c82)
(cherry picked from commit 88ec71469795c81689da02c9fd93f2540b9f13c8)

commit_message:
Only validate admin and public host in local_subnet cidr

When multiple subnets are configured validations where failing
becuase the admin and public host addresses where checked
for all subnets. The admin and public host addresses should
only be validated against the cidr of the local_subnet.

Closes-Bug: #1791088
Change-Id: Ie9a6f88cc449c135593a0df0426e4d8054b38183
(cherry picked from commit c0c66a93c0641ebf591124cb05ee50e5ed5fda07)

commit_message:
Remove airship/berth from infra

This removes the airship/berth project from OpenStack Infra,
as agreed upon at the Denver PTG and in subsequent Airship
IRC team meetings.

The PS to zero-out the project has already merged:
https://review.opendev.org/#/c/670924/

Change-Id: Ibd6c51710bce82baa79d6733064f69f3f0e2c8e8

commit_message:
Convert dynamic includes to static imports

When task/role files are included using include_tasks, tags are not
passed to the included tasks. As a result, tags like neutron-config
do not have the intended effect. This patch changes include_tasks
to import_tasks for all cases where dynamic vars or loops are not used
so that tags are properly handled.

Reference -
https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/user_guide/playbooks_reuse.html
https://bugs.launchpad.net/openstack-ansible/+bug/1815043

Change-Id: I14bfdc0e488ffd2db1d0b82afd773674819ee0f4

commit_message:
Convert dynamic includes to static imports

When task/role files are included using include_tasks, tags are not
passed to the included tasks. As a result, tags like neutron-config
do not have the intended effect. This patch changes include_tasks
to import_tasks for all cases where dynamic vars or loops are not used
so that tags are properly handled.

Reference -
https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/user_guide/playbooks_reuse.html
https://bugs.launchpad.net/openstack-ansible/+bug/1815043

Change-Id: Ifc210d2fc7f217105d83c0ad4f86a3939c6c93d3

commit_message:
sonobuoy: Support storing results on host

Currently, results are stored using an emptyDir volume. This change adds
support for storing results using a customizable hostPath. When storing
results in a hostPath, results can still be obtained form the hostPath
while result publishing is disabled.

Change-Id: Ibd01da23a8e74a54f500429cf0ba8ca72f2ac77d

subject: Convert dynamic includes to static imports
messages: [{'account_id': 28619, 'date': '2019-07-19 12:37:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.'}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2019-07-19 16:10:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 25023, 'date': '2019-07-19 16:29:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-07-19 12:37:27.000000000', 'message': 'Convert dynamic includes to static imports

When task/role files are included using include_tasks, tags are not
passed to the included tasks. As a result, tags like neutron-config
do not have the intended effect. This patch changes include_tasks
to import_tasks for all cases where dynamic vars or loops are not used
so that tags are properly handled.

Reference -
https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/user_guide/playbooks_reuse.html
https://bugs.launchpad.net/openstack-ansible/+bug/1815043

Change-Id: I7c4c7e6887cc756998ce028355402705a45e18ed
(cherry picked from commit 373e2d3042713ed8c1f4c9a47c435e0d18f0a103)
'}]
commit_message:
Convert dynamic includes to static imports

When task/role files are included using include_tasks, tags are not
passed to the included tasks. As a result, tags like neutron-config
do not have the intended effect. This patch changes include_tasks
to import_tasks for all cases where dynamic vars or loops are not used
so that tags are properly handled.

Reference -
https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/user_guide/playbooks_reuse.html
https://bugs.launchpad.net/openstack-ansible/+bug/1815043

Change-Id: I7c4c7e6887cc756998ce028355402705a45e18ed
(cherry picked from commit 373e2d3042713ed8c1f4c9a47c435e0d18f0a103)

retirement; stable branches will be maintained for some

branch to re-enable testing.

commit_message:
Fix - L3 Conntrack Helper validator

'type:string' is validated by length, the definition was
passing in validators.validate_string instead of a number.
In python3 this causes a TypeError:
 '>' not supported between instances of 'int' and 'function'

Set the length to 64, matching the db model:
https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/src/branch/master/neutron/db/models/conntrack_helper.py#L32

Related-Bug: #1823633
Change-Id: Idd9b442a30de294ce3fc97069cadba4457d746ab

commit_message:
Add possibility to disable running stadium projects tests

This patch adds possibility to disable running of tests related to:
* networking-bgpvpn,
* neutron-fwaas,
* networking-sfc

which were moved to neutron-tempest-plugin repo recently.
This will be useful when tests will be run for one of
stable branches up to Stein, in which those tests are still
in project's repo.

Change-Id: I61dc252920154e7e0998eb2c7c1f026814796cdf

commit_message:
[mini-mirror] Add node selector label to pod spec

This PS adds node selector labels to deployment pod spec to avoid
mini mirror from getting deployed to compute nodes.

Change-Id: Ie898616e4d15ce6ce1736df863b3514e03433ee7

commit_message:
Horizon: Expose additional security config params

Expose additional Horizon security params in accordance with the
OpenStack Security Guide [0]

- ALLOWED_HOSTS
- HORIZON_IMAGES_UPLOAD_MODE

[0] https://docs.openstack.org/security-guide/dashboard/domains-dashboard-upgrades-basic-web-server-configuration.html

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/635545

Change-Id: I071c8fbfc5ea9b41d3c35840e342d83349ae1613

commit_message:
Convert percona-cluster to Zaza

Convert amulet tests to zaza.
Add additional tests for new cold boot actions.
Use multi-model tests.yaml for different tests for bionic and xenial.

commit_message:
Notify bootstrapped action

It turns out a subsequent required step after a cold boot bootstrap is
notifying the cluster of the new bootstrap UUID.

The notify-bootstrapped action should be run on a different node than
the one which ran the bootstrap-pxc action.

This action will ensure the cluster converges on the correct bootstrap
UUID.

A subsequent patch stacked on this one will include tests for the new
cold boot actions.

Change-Id: Idee12d5f7e28498c5ab6ccb9605f751c6427ac30
Partial-Bug: #1744393

commit_message:
Install libvirt-client for nova-compute after OS upgrade

This package is required to avoid docker-puppet.py errors:

Error: /Stage[main]/Nova::Compute::Libvirt_guests/File_line[/etc/sysconfig/libvirt-guests ON_BOOT]: Could not evaluate: No such file or directory @ rb_sysopen - /etc/sysconfig/libvirt-guests
Error: /Stage[main]/Nova::Compute::Libvirt_guests/File_line[/etc/sysconfig/libvirt-guests ON_SHUTDOWN]: Could not evaluate: No such file or directory @ rb_sysopen - /etc/sysconfig/libvirt-guests
Error: /Stage[main]/Nova::Compute::Libvirt_guests/File_line[/etc/sysconfig/libvirt-guests SHUTDOWN_TIMEOUT]: Could not evaluate: No such file or directory @ rb_sysopen - /etc/sysconfig/libvirt-guests

Change-Id: I3fe7a82579ba63c7e914af5d919a001933ab8545
Partial-Bug: #1831690

commit_message:
Re-Add facter cache for container configurations

Rather than running all the facts for every invocation of
container-puppet.py, let's cache the facts for the entire container
config step.  This is similar to what used to happen when we ran puppet
in a single instance for a given step. This improves the time it takes
puppet tp execute within the containers. When systems have large number
of interfaces, the fact generation for puppet can come to a crawl given
that puppet is not supposed to be invoked multiple times in parallel. By
pre-caching the facts, we eliminate the need for puppet to do the
network (and other fact) related lookups when running container
configuration generation.

This patch includes logic to exclude the puppet caching dirs that we
mount as read only in the config containers.

Change-Id: I94002572ec7ac1767fbfbfdf4c6fa6fbf0cd58d5
Closes-Bug: #1837082
Closes-Bug: #1835959

commit_message:
Remove extraconfig/services directory

... and move the services into the deployment directory.

The extraconfig/services directory was initially created for
experimental services using an interface that was work in progress but
is now stable enough, so the services can live among the others for
simplification.

Change-Id: I2bd0b169ed18ea2fccfea4475402dd73076924c8

messages:
[{'account_id': 11805, 'date': '2019-06-24 19:12:31.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2019-06-26 07:33:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

Please don't change tox.ini, it is correct."}, {'account_id': 23851, 'date': '2019-07-01 10:32:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

I'd leave py3
if we really need to change I'd put "py36,py37"'}, {'account_id': 11805, 'date': '2019-07-02 18:29:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Adding py36 and py37 would mean running 'tox' would run both, so the idea was to just run the latest supported python version by default. Users can always run 'tox -e py36' if they want without py36 being defined as a default env."}, {'account_id': 11805, 'date': '2019-07-02 18:33:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

And, as mentioned in other reviews, the problem with running a generic 'py3' is that you have no idea what distro release developers are running tox on so could be py34 while the gate runs py36/py37 which are much different."}, {'account_id': 11805, 'date': '2019-07-19 14:37:40.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

Abandoning since enabling py37 in tox.ini is a stretch goal and the completion criteria is already satisfied for zuul jobs. https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/train/python3-updates.html'}]

[{'account_id': 6796, 'date': '2019-05-30 13:43:18.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 6796, 'date': '2019-05-30 13:44:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

not sure if we'll ever want this exposed in the templates or if the puppet-tripleo changes are sufficient considering people will be able to override the hieradata using ExtraConfig"}, {'account_id': 6796, 'date': '2019-06-27 12:11:58.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 6796, 'date': '2019-06-28 10:44:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

note that only scenario004 is using the env file I am changing'}, {'account_id': 6796, 'date': '2019-07-15 13:35:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Patch Set 2 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 25402, 'date': '2019-07-16 10:35:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2019-07-16 12:46:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 9003, 'date': '2019-07-16 13:21:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 16643, 'date': '2019-07-16 21:31:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1

The commit message is a little confusing to me; these options already existed; and we're adding them to the environment file to make it easier for folks to consume/override if using an external ceph cluster... 

The commit message however, talks about future direction?"}, {'account_id': 6796, 'date': '2019-07-17 09:13:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> The commit message is a little confusing to me; these options
 > already existed; and we're adding them to the environment file to
 > make it easier for folks to consume/override if using an external
 > ceph cluster...
 > 
 > The commit message however, talks about future direction?

hi Goutham, thanks for the review!

unmanaged Ganesha service instead of deploying one together with
the Share service. This change allows for configuration of the CephFS

to keep the Ganesha service deployment under control of TripleO but
still point it to an external Ceph cluster.

commit_message:
Allow for configuration of the Manila CephFS backend with a remote Ceph

When deploying Manila with CephFS backend it might be preferable
to keep the Ganesha service deployment under control of TripleO but
still point it to an external Ceph cluster.

From version 4.0.0rc9 [1] ceph-ansible is capable of deploying Ganesha and
configure it to use an external Ceph cluster. We can use this feature
TripleO enabling the CephNfs and CephClient services on those roles
where Ganesha needs to go.

It will be possible to deploy Manila with a CephFS backend together
with Ganesha (pacemaker managed) and point them to an external Ceph
cluster combining the two environments:
- manila-cephfsganesha-config.yaml
- ceph-ansible/ceph-ansible-external.yaml

1. https://github.com/ceph/ceph-ansible/commit/6a6785b719d126cf54ebad8b2a22c97d90afd05e

Change-Id: Iae674127cf948fbc007ee2be96041221f7584ce7
Implements: blueprint manila-external-ganesha

[{'created': '2019-07-16 15:50:31.000000000', 'message': 'Use bash executible when checking PIPESTATUS

Bu default, ansible shell module uses /bin/sh.
Thereas there is no $PIPESTATUS available for piped
commands.

Fix this be explicitly specifying an appropriate
executible for ansible.

Closes-bug: #1836596

Change-Id: Ic70a11281b471a51698490bd899c99dafaba1e35
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>
'}, {'created': '2019-07-17 11:32:11.000000000', 'message': 'Use bash executible when checking PIPESTATUS

'}, {'created': '2019-07-17 11:46:36.000000000', 'message': 'Use pipefail instead of checking PIPESTATUS

It seems that the pipefail option works more reliably than
$PIPESTATUS. The former also provides an established pattern for
the shell commands executed via ansible in tripleo.

'}]
commit_message:
Use pipefail instead of checking PIPESTATUS

It seems that the pipefail option works more reliably than
$PIPESTATUS. The former also provides an established pattern for
the shell commands executed via ansible in tripleo.

Closes-bug: #1836596

Change-Id: Ic70a11281b471a51698490bd899c99dafaba1e35
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>

Change-Id: I5e2c92a60f73b75a144228fd13ac31fff990a038

commit_message:
Add a suffix for tmpwatch

Change 641608 introduces tmpwatch into logrotate-crond container.
However, LogrotatePurgeAfterDays parameter is parsed in hours because
there is no suffix to the value. This commit adds a suffix, 'd' to the
value.

Closes-Bug: #1836848
Change-Id: I5e2c92a60f73b75a144228fd13ac31fff990a038
(cherry picked from commit a0b9f90a2eefb7d65a72503a0a970451efda1d04)

commit_message:
Expose 'mem_stats_period_seconds' config parameter

Add support for configuring 'mem_stats_period_seconds'
libvirt config option.

When using the balloon stats in the XML configuration, user gets
latency violation in guests, because balloon stats causes QEMU to
periodically send asynchronous requests to balloon driver in the guest.

Conflicts:
      manifests/compute/libvirt.pp

Resolved conflicts related to other parameter defined in
newer releases but not available in this release.

Change-Id: If69d32fb4b718b97efbfbe0d58a37966af957be9
(cherry picked from commit 05d7733e2a754fb45b0fb76b784b44339e78745c)
(cherry picked from commit 4c5881a746c8c1dfed9d6da5864bf18f3834c8e7)
(cherry picked from commit 070f926a65412dfe4c81db1329b8978415b75dc1)

commit_message:
Expose 'mem_stats_period_seconds' config parameter

Add support for configuring 'mem_stats_period_seconds'
libvirt config option.

When using the balloon stats in the XML configuration, user gets
latency violation in guests, because balloon stats causes QEMU to
periodically send asynchronous requests to balloon driver in the guest.

Conflicts:
      manifests/compute/libvirt.pp
      spec/classes/nova_compute_libvirt_spec.rb

Resolved conflicts related to other parameter defined in
newer releases but not available in this release.

Change-Id: If69d32fb4b718b97efbfbe0d58a37966af957be9
(cherry picked from commit 05d7733e2a754fb45b0fb76b784b44339e78745c)
(cherry picked from commit 4c5881a746c8c1dfed9d6da5864bf18f3834c8e7)

commit_message:
WIP: using tripleo-ci buildimages with rdo rhel8 fs1 ovb

The oooci_buildimages var is defined/set for rdo rhel8 fs1 ovb job
and allows us to use the tripleo-ci role. The flag causes the image
script to ommit adding the image name so that all the images
specified in the config files are built.

This will allow us to use the oooci-build-images role for fs1 ovb
rhel 8 job - more info and tracked by tripleo ci squad at [1].
Related review at [2]

[1] https://tree.taiga.io/project/tripleo-ci-board/task/1154
[2] https://review.opendev.org/669844
Change-Id: I95e3da301bbfa4bc49ce9fbd36b4dd6c6f3eb7ee

commit_message:
Change cinder bootstrap script

This commit changes the cinder template bootstrap script
to use the openstack client instead of the cinder client
to list volume types.

Change-Id: I5a4b22ab4475d503b3e8fa46cd3c56a0b40863e0
Signed-off-by: Teresa Ho <teresa.ho@windriver.com>

commit_message:
build: use upper-constraints.txt from rally-openstack

We had all of the upper-constraints hardwired inside the role
which was not ideal.  This patch grabs the latest upper-constraints
as we are installing the latest package in this case.

Change-Id: Icfac74a031d9059d50772d8423c5ba3f6aa00407

'}, {'created': '2019-07-09 14:48:34.000000000', 'message': "Add support for multiple client spaces

Some users may not want to expose all vault clients
to the same networks. In particular they might want
to have some on the default access network and some
on an external network. This patch adds support for
new 'external' binding which clients can use to
talk to the vault api.

commit_message:
Add support for multiple client spaces

Some users may not want to expose all vault clients
to the same networks. In particular they might want
to have some on the default access network and some
on an external network. This patch adds support for
new 'external' binding which clients can use to
talk to the vault api.

Change-Id: I0d393c71dcb127b14b8ffcacbd03bbf68f81a53b
Closes-Bug: #1826892

commit_message:
Add a suffix for tmpwatch

Change 641608 introduces tmpwatch into logrotate-crond container.
However, LogrotatePurgeAfterDays parameter is parsed in hours because
there is no suffix to the value. This commit adds a suffix, 'd' to the
value.

Closes-Bug: #1836848
Change-Id: I5e2c92a60f73b75a144228fd13ac31fff990a038
(cherry picked from commit a0b9f90a2eefb7d65a72503a0a970451efda1d04)
(cherry picked from commit 76356dc4f2a87cc8035a8b420f7886b5c7b24c82)
